column5: Analysis for Probabilistic and Risk Reduction Decision Support Fire Weather Services. This Statement of Work is to support efforts of the National Weather Service (NWS) to improve decision support services for fire weather support. Using social science methods and risk communication expertise, the desire is to identify how probabilistic weather information can most effectively influence fire-related decision-making to protect lives and property and enhance the economy

column5: The IMET program needs 10 balloon inflation kits to complete the radiosonde observing system in 10 additional AMRS systems.  These balloon inflation kits allow the IMET to safely and confidently fill the upper air balloon to the appropriate level to complete a successful radiosonde launch and gather valuable atmospheric observations.  The radiosonde atmospheric observation is a three-dimensional profile of the atmosphere at periodic time intervals for a specific location.

column4: Extend existing NCEP Networx / Lumen contract # RA133W10NC2153 by 12 months to allow the NWS adequate time to complete the ongoing transition to N-WAVE / EIS
column5: Lumen’s WAN circuits transmit meteorological data between various NWS data processing sites, including supercomputing sites, dissemination sites, regional headquarters, NCEP Centers, and NWS forecast offices where the data is used as a basis for weather forecasts and warnings that protect American life and property. Without these network circuits, the NWS Offices of Dissemination and Central Processing cannot perform the mission for which they are responsible.  NWS requires the 12 month extension to allow adequate time to complete the transition to NWAVE.

column4: NEC-VESSEL CHARTER FOR COASTAL SHARK BOTTOM LONGLINE SURVEY
column5: The purpose of this acquisition is to provide NOAA/NMFS/NEFSC and the NMFS Office of Highly Migratory Species (HMS) services for the Coastal Shark Bottom Longline Survey. The services will include sampling for the 12th and 13th years of a bottom longline (fixed gear) survey in the western North Atlantic Ocean. The Apex Predators Program of the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC) is requesting the charter of one longline fishing vessel. The vessel will be involved in conducting sampling of coastal sharks using bottom longline gear. This contract spans a total of 4 years including a 2-year base period and 2-year option period.

column5: The Department is seeking support from a contractor for establishment of and support for an effective CHIPS Environmental Compliance Program.  The Environmental Compliance Program will facilitate agency and applicant compliance with all applicable environmental and cultural resource laws, regulations, and policies, as well as facilitating innovative approaches that go beyond compliance to achieve sustainability and other program objectives.The contractor would work closely with the Department’s CHIPS environmental compliance team in completing the defined objectives and would draw on its own expertise, supplemented as necessary by external advisors.  Comprehensive and defensible reviews of federal financial assistance applications and issues affecting proposed projects are essential in supporting the federal financial assistance process of the CHIPS Incentives Program. column5: The contractor shall develop a basic understanding and knowledge of what PPSAD does and using this understanding shall provide new ideas, suggestions, and upgrades to the PPSAD’s user engagement policies and plans and carry out website oversight for PPSAD.  The contractor shall become knowledgeable with all of PPSAD’s tools and analysis capabilities.To that end, PPSAD requires contract support to ensure meetings and other events are coordinated, scheduled, and changed as needed; action items are accurately tracked; and the overall flow of information continues uninterrupted. Preparation of briefing materials must be done and edited, and information must be properly disseminated to all of NOAA.

column5: Optical photothermal IR microscope that meets the following minimum technical requirements.  a.	Have tunable quantum cascade laser(s) that cover at least (3000-2700) cm-1 and (1800-1000) cm-1 ranges and an appropriate optical switching box b.	Have the ability to collect spectra in imaging and spectroscopy modes, which includes imaging at spectral ratios of user defined wavenumbersc.	Have Microscope with switchable 10x visible and 40x visible/IR objectivesd.	Have ability for spatial resolution in imaging mode below 500 nm and capabilities to extend resolution below 300 nm on manufacturer’s standard particle controle.	Includes visible 532 nm laser for probe that can changed by the user and seamlessly integrated in the software as sample requirements change f. column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) seeks information on commercial vendors that can provide an Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) metal silicon III-V etching system to support nanofabrication in the Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) user facility.  The system will be sited and used as a shared resource accessible to researchers from industry, academia, NIST, and other government agencies in the CNST NanoFab.  The ICP metal silicon III-V etching system is a pattern transfer tool that uses hydrogen bromide (HBr), Chlorine (Cl2), boron trichloride (BCl3), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) and other chemicals to fabricate micron- and nano-scale structures in metals, silicon, III-V compounds and other materials.  Applications include fabricating nano-semiconductor and nano-photonic devices.  The NanoFab currently operates an ICP System originally purchased in 2007 and is heavily used to etch various metals,
column21: {'workspace_number': 'REQUIREMENTS-23-0113', 'date_created': '2022-12-19', 'organization_unit': 'NIST - ALP', 'months': '24', 'years': '2', 'type_of_awardee': 'Unrestricted - No Set Aside Used', 'competition_strategy': 'Sole Source', 'new_requirement_or_recompete': 'New Requirement', 'incumbent_contractor_name': 'nan', 'awarded_contract_order_number': 'nan', 'anticipated_contract_vehicle': 'nan', 'point_of_contact_name': 'KERRY SIEBEIN', 'point_of_contact_email': 'KERRY.SIEBEIN@NIST.GOV', 'does_this_acquisition_contain_information_technology': 'N', 'date_created_or_modified': 'NaT', 'awarded': 'No'}

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) seeks information on commercial vendors that can provide an Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) cryo-silicon and dielectric materials etching system to support nanofabrication in the Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) user facility.  The system will be sited and used as a shared resource accessible to researchers from industry, academia, NIST, and other government agencies in the CNST NanoFab.  The ICP cryo-silicon and dielectric materials etching system is a pattern transfer tool that uses fluorocarbon compounds and other chemicals to fabricate micron- and nano-scale structures in silicon and dielectric materials.  Applications include fabricating nano-semiconductor and nano-photonic devices. column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) seeks to purchase an Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) Etch System to support nanofabrication in the Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) user facility.  The system will be sited and used as a shared resource accessible to researchers from industry, academia, NIST, and other government agencies in the CNST NanoFab.  The System is a pattern transfer tool that uses Hydrogen Bromide (HBr), Chlorine (Cl2) and other chemicals to fabricate micron- and nano-scale structures in silicon substrate. Applications include fabricating semiconductor and photonic devices. The NanoFab currently operates a Plasma-Therm Shuttleline ICP etching system originally purchased in 2003 and is heavily used to fabricate a wide variety of silicon-based devices.  However, the current system is reaching the end of life and some parts are obsolete.  To provide uninterrupted support to NanoFab u

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) seeks information on commercial vendors that can provide a mechanical clamp based deep reactive ion etching (DRIE) system to support nanofabrication in the Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) user facility.  The system will be sited and used as a shared resource accessible to researchers from industry, academia, NIST, and other government agencies in the CNST NanoFab.  The mechanical clamp based deep silicon etching system is a pattern transfer tool that uses the Bosch process to fabricate three dimensional structures in silicon. Applications include silicon photonic devices for temperature, pressure, humidity sensing and various micro/nano semiconductor devices.The NanoFab currently operates a mechanical clamp-based DRIE system originally purchased in 2003 and is heavily used to fabricate a wide variety of silicon-based devices. column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)/Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) enables science and industry by providing essential measurement methods, instrumentation, and standards to support all phases of nanotechnology development from discovery to production.  The Nanofabrication Operations Group of the CNST has the mission of advancing measurement science by developing novel nanofabrication and nanomanufacturing techniques. NIST’s CNST NanoFab seeks to acquire an open load reactive ion etch system for installation into a class 100 multi-user CNST NanoFab cleanroom facility. The clean room facility is located at the NIST Gaithersburg, MD site and is used as a shared resource that is accessible to researchers from industry, academia, NIST, and other government agencies. column4: HUBNER Photonics Computer-controlled tunable laser system
column5: This new laser system would replace an obsolete 1980’s technology dye laser based on the use of carcinogenic fluorescent molecules, requiring a high power pump laser to initiate emission.  This huge safety upgrade will also stream-line experimental run times (from days to minutes) by dramatically reducing alignment procedure and enabling an order of magnitude increase in Raman signals.

column5: OHCS is seeking a web-based employee and labor relations research resource and tools repository that meet the following requirements, and offers the following resources/tools, or equivalent:o	Quick Start Guides  — Guides that provide overviews and interpretive guidance of EEO, employee relations and labor relations (Union), classification and staffing topics linking noteworthy cases, statutes, regulations and additional resources.o	Is Federal Government Specific – for ease of use, only contains information that pertains to Federal employment case law, not private sector or state.o	Summaries of MSPB and Administrative Law Judge Case Decisions and Arbitration Awards — permits staff to quickly scan search results and call up the full text if further detail is desired. Written by attorney editors, summaries make research easier and are protected under copyright.o	Case Central — lists the latest Case Files and Hotlaws by court author

column4: Blanket Purchase Agreement for Court Reporting and Transcription Services
column5: The objective of this procurement is to result in a Blanket Purchase Agreement (BPA) with a vendor experienced in working with the Federal Government that can provide the services of both court reporters and transcriptionists.  The BPA would be for a base year and four option years to be exercised at the convenience of the Government, based on the availability of funds.E&C conducts AD/CVD investigations and administrative reviews to determine whether goods are being dumped or unfairly subsidized.  The parties participating in these proceedings can  request that a hearing be held.  A hearing provides these parties the opportunity to present arguments before E&C staff, prior to the issuance of a final decision.  At these hearings, E&C requires court reporting and transcribing services to document what is discussed during the hearing.  Following the completion of the hearing, the report must be transcribed to produce an official transcript

column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) adheres to Homeland Security Presidential Directive 12 (HSPD-12) requirements through the Identify, Credential, and Access Management (ICAM) initiative. ICAM includes information technology (IT) programs, processes, technologies, and personnel used to create trusted digital identity representations of individuals and Non-Person Entities (NPEs), bind these identities to credentials that serve as a proxy for the individual or NPE to provide authorized access to NOAA resources, and access transactions on NOAA systems.

column4: Digital Identity Support for A Modular Guide to Modern Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
column5: To promote continuous and responsible innovation within the Digital Identity ecosystem, NIST: Creates Guidelines such as the Special Publication 800-63: Digital Identity Guidelines or 1800 series SPs targeting implementation; Develops Standards such as Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) and contributes to international standards such as those developed in ISO, IETF, W3C, FIDO, and IETF; and Conducts foundational and applied research to advance knowledge of Digital Identity Technology and Processes and bridge the gap between standards, guidance, and implementation – often resulting in NIST Internal Reports, NIST Interagency Reports (NIST IRs), White Papers, or Implementation Guides.

column5: This requirement seeks a public affairs expert contractor support to craft and implement media engagement strategies to educate the public safety community about the NPSBN, as well as to raise awareness among this critical audience of the FirstNet Authority.As part of its public safety engagement and advocacy role, the FirstNet Authority is seeking to expand outreach to the public safety community at the local level in target states as identified by the FirstNet Authority.Local and digital media outreach are tools to reach and engage first responders and other public safety officials at the local level. Through these approaches, the FirstNet Authority aims to educate these communities on the FirstNet network and increase awareness of the FirstNet Authority’s role in driving the network forward to meet public safety’s needs.

column4: Seized Drug Interlaboratory Study Test Solutions
column5: The Material Measurement Laboratory (MML) within the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) is planning to conduct a series of interlaboratory studies for seized drug analysts in the forensic science community. As part of these studies, MML is seeking commercial partners who can generate test solutions that will be provided directly to forensic laboratories participating in the interlaboratory studies. It is expected that multiple interlaboratory studies will be conducted each year for the next three to five years to support this effort. Requirements for the test solutions are provided below. While the interlaboratory studies will predominantly use solutions, identifying commercial partners who can generate, and ship, solid samples is also of interest.

column5: Optical components for Neutron Optics Project: 3 m of neutron guide for NG6, shutter components for BT2, and alignment stages for the Neutron Microscope Wolter optic.  The guide network for NG6 is missing the last 3 m of the full height M=2 guides.  In order to complete the instrument, we require 3 m of M=2 supermirror deposited on Borkon glass.  The order will be placed on the NCNR guide BOA.  The cost of components for the BT2 shutter and primary collimator has significantly exceeded the initial IE allocation. Additional funding is required to complete the upgrades and significantly improve the safety of the instrument. The Wolter optics will arrive by SEP 2023, we require two dedicated 5-axis motorized alignment stages to produce high quality spatial- and time-resolved images.

column4: Large active area fuel cell test stand
column5: "Brief: Replacement for the current automotive scale fuel cell test stand.Justification:  The current automotive scale fuel cell test stand that is no longer supported by General Motors rendering in nearly useless. We can obtain support for the new stand from the test stand manufacturer.  Costs for the new stand will be recovered through amortized fuel cell testing fees.  Since many companies want to use the test stand we will continue to bring additional funding to NIST through it's service in the NIST neutron imaging program.  This test stand is vital to maintain NIST's role as an international leader in automotive fuel cell research.  Maintaining this capability at NIST will allow the NIST neutron imaging team to bring in additional funding to NIST."

column5: A cryogenic detector development system capable of rapid detector cooldown and holding at 10 mK is key infrastructure needed by Div. 682 to develop a new technologies in charged particle detection in collaboration Div. 687. The main stakeholder is the Neutron Physics Group, where this system would allow the development of CP-TKIDs, a fundamentally new detector technology that promises to dramatically improve capabilities in low energy charged particle detection. New detector approaches are ultimately  required to move beyond incremental improvements in precision tests of the laws of physics underlying the SI and will also find important applications throughout nuclear physics. This user-friendly cryogenic system which will be used in place of an existing wet dilution refrigeration system, will not only significantly reduce operational overhead and cost but is also well-suited for the rapid turnaround needed to advance this technology. T

column5: Install a replacement of the existing fire alarm system to integrate with the newly installed Siemens Fire Alarm Panel.  The existing AOML Facility was built in early 1970’s.  The original fire alarm panel still controls a majority of the building and is beyond its useful life.  Installing new devices throughout the facility and connecting them to the newly installed Siemens fire alarm panel will significantly improve the overall reliability of the system, eliminate nuisance alarm and ensure the safety of AOML staff.BOD date is based on a 2nd quarter FY 2023 availability of funds (31MAR23) with adequate time allowed for design, solicitation, equipment procurement and installation.

column5: The AOML Facility was built in early 1970’s.  The original fire suppression system was designed to provide limited sprinkler coverage to the atrium area and feed fire hose cabinets located throughout the building.  Sprinkler systems have been added to areas on the 1st and 3rd floors during renovation projects.  This project will upgrade and extend the existing system throughout the entire building per current life/safety code requirements.  This will include an evaluation of the existing standpipes that are currently located in the 4 stair towers.Install an extension of the existing fire suppression system to provide coverage for the unprotected areas of the AOML facility.

column5: It is estimated that 50 natural and technological events, such as oil spills and response exercises will occur, primarily in coastal areas of the United States, each year during the contract period that will require the Contractor to provide support. These responses can involve complex decisions associated with natural resource protection priorities, shoreline cleanup strategies, and natural resource damage assessment. The Contractor shall ensure that response personnel have training necessary to work within a National Interagency Incident Management System Incident Command System.  The Contractor shall maintain this capability in an on-call status 24-hours a day, 365-days a year.

column4: Asymmetric Flow Field Flow Fractionation with Tandem Light Scattering Detectors Instrument Suite
column5: Asymmetric Flow Field Flow Fractionation with Tandem Light Scattering Detectors Instrument Suite including installation, training, warranty and 3 years maintenance.  The instrument must be capable of:  1) size-based separation of colloidal nanoscale materials; 2) minimal dilution of sample during separation and before online measurements; 3) online measurement of particles’ radius of gyration; 4) online measurement of particles’ translational diffusion coefficient; 5) online measurement of particles’ molar mass; 6) online measurement and calculation of particle number concentration for each particle size; and/or 7) online measurement of particles’ electrophoretic mobility and zeta potential.

column5: The primary goal of the Design Selection Phase is to conduct the research, testing, integration and operational planning and design work to inform the selection and maintenance of the 2030 Census operational design, factoring in past census experiences, evolving technology, and the changing world. The selected operational design will drive the work and future contracting opportunities of the Development and Integration Phase, which focuses on updating and maintaining the operational design, building, modifying, or acquiring an integrated set of IT and operational solutions, conducting a dress rehearsal to test these solutions, and ensuring readiness for the final program phase, Peak Production and Close-Out.

column5: To provide Information Technology and Support Services for Warning Decision Training Division (WDTD) and Storm Prediction Center (SPC) in Norman, OK.  Base plus two option years. column5: This acquisition would be for real-time and retrospective satellite imagery for situational awareness through the remote sensing capabilities provided by GHGSAT. This would enhance NOAA/SAB's ability to monitor and understand the sources of greenhouse gas emissions and inform policy decisions aimed at reducing said emissions. column4: Detection, Characterizing, and Mitigation of Passive Sensor Data Corrupting Emissions (DMiPS)
column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is interested in exploring methodologies, services, tools, and capabilities that can be applied towards detecting, identifying, characterizing, and mitigating anthropogenic radio frequency (RF) emissions within or adjacent to the RF bands used for passive sensing by Earth exploration satellites. Domestic and International radio regulations also contain frequency ranges where no radio frequency transmissions are allowed, although it’s possible that excessive anthropogenic energy may be present regardless.  Adjacent services often have regulatory limits regarding the level of out-of-band emissions that are allowed from those services that may fall into a nearby passive band. As current and future telecommunication services, satellite and broadband-aviation uplinks in millimeter wave bands are implemented there are potential interference risks to passive sensors, to include operati

column5: GENERAL SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS:1.	Cryogen-free: The Government requires a system in which liquid helium is not needed as a consumable.  A system that requires the use of liquid helium will not be accepted.   A system requiring liquid nitrogen is acceptable. The minimum acceptable period of time between liquid nitrogen replenishment is 7 days.2.	Optical access: a.	This system must be capable of providing line-of-sight access from outside the cryostat into the center (within approximately 5 cm) of the coldest stage. The window(s) or flange(s) providing this optical access must be removable and, for future modification, it is required that they conform to the geometry of a standard commercial flange (e.g., KF/NW). b.	Working distance: The distance from the outer surface of the outermost window to the inner surface of the innermost window must be less than 30 mm.  Please note that this is not a specification for the distance to t

column5: The overall objectives of this BAA are to identify technologies with the capability to achieve the above goal of improving NOAA’s ground processing, determine the status of these technologies today, determine how they are projected to evolve in the near future, and perform a value/feasibility assessment of them.  For this purpose, under the NOAA Joint Venture Program, we are looking to leverage technologies and, jointly with other partners, achieve the following objectives for each of the three focus areas.  Objective A (Study):  Perform studies to define different approaches to meet NOAA technical requirements described below. Objective B (Demonstration): Conduct a demonstration, on a limited scale, of approach(es) that meet the technical requirements described below.

column5: The requirement is for a laboratory-based, “turn-key” solution providing selectable vacuum- and extreme-ultraviolet (EUV, VUV) wavelengths.  The project being pursued will allow the measurement of nanoscale semiconductor patterns by shining EUV and VUV light onto such samples and measuring with a camera system the reflected, diffracted, and scattered light to determine the dimensions of these patterned features.  Such projects have been carried out at longer wavelengths at NIST but this requirement is necessary to reduce the wavelength of light used to provide better information about nanoscale dimensions especially as semiconductor dimensions continue to decrease.  As EUV and VUV light are absorbed by air, this source will output into a vacuum.  The VUV+EUV Source will allow the isolation of certain wavelengths to improve our metrology and will also be augmented by equipment to characterize this VUV and EUV light..

column5: Illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing activities threaten ocean ecosystems, sustainable fisheries, coastal economies, and food security. The maritime officers who patrol and enforce the most vulnerable parts of the ocean do not operate with the most advanced technology and monitoring vast expanses of coastal and offshore fisheries is challenging. Many countries employ different tools to combat IUU, including setting catch limits and quotas for fisheries, providing bycatch reduction gear, zoning their marine areas and in some cases satellite monitoring.While multiple fisheries management and enforcement agencies are working with the International Maritime Organization to boost accountability requirements aboard commercial fishing vessels across the globe, it is doing little to combat IUU fishing. To support the broader problem of fisheries management, surveillance must be safely and efficiently expanded.Collaborative par

column4: Immersive Visualization Environment Upgrade for High Performance Computing and Visualization Research
column5: This Immersive Visualization Environment (IVE), along with the software that the Group develops is on a critical path for all research in the Group. Its role is critical in HPCVG’s High Performance Computing work as it serves to speed code development and enable quick checking for errors as well as validation tests. It enables the visualization, measurement on visualizations, and analysis of results. This has led to solving critical outstanding problems in industry and contributing to the creation of standard reference materials and data. For example, it played a crucial role in the development of the standard reference materials for cement paste, mortar, and concrete.

column5: NIST is working on a project that requires an infrared telescope system to make accurate spectral irradiance measurements of the light from standard stars in the wavelength range between 850 nm and 2500 nm. Observations will be made at high altitude above 2600 m (8600 feet) in dry (low precipitable water vapor) environments to maximize access to clear skies and minimize telluric effects (e.g., aerosols).   These measurements will then serve as standard calibration spectra for multiple stakeholders who operate other astronomical instruments and satellite instruments.

column4: A Table-top Vacuum- and Extreme-Ultraviolet Source
column5: The requirement is for a laboratory-based, “turn-key” solution providing selectable vacuum- and extreme-ultraviolet (EUV, VUV) wavelengths.  The project being pursued will allow the measurement of nanoscale semiconductor patterns by shining EUV and VUV light onto such samples and measuring with a camera system the reflected, diffracted, and scattered light to determine the dimensions of these patterned features.  Such projects have been carried out at longer wavelengths at NIST but this requirement is necessary to reduce the wavelength of light used to provide better information about nanoscale dimensions especially as semiconductor dimensions continue to decrease.  As EUV and VUV light are absorbed by air, this source will output into a vacuum.  The VUV+EUV Source will allow the isolation of certain wavelengths to improve our metrology and will also be augmented by equipment to characterize this VUV and EUV light..

column5: FAME time-series database and renew FAME license subscriptions. column5: The purpose of this contract is to obtain services of a Contractor for the development of 2030 Census Training framework which encompasses a working model of Learning Record Store, Learner Portal, Virtual Classroom and online training modules. The goal is to extend and build upon the success of 2020 Census training framework for all operations that employed the blended, staggered training approach in 2030 Census. Mastery of survey concepts and procedural skills on operating the instrument are critical for effective transfer of learning in the actual field work. Since our training audience has limited or no prior knowledge, complex knowledge and tasks should be decomposed into sub-topics and supported with targeted scaffolding so trainees can thoroughly understand and absorb what they are learning. Self-assessment and graded formative assessments will be integrated into the modules to identify high and low performing trainees who

column4: Vessel Operations - Lake Michigan Field Station, Muskegon, MI
column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL) operates a fleet of vessels ranging from 12’-85’ in length on the Great Lakes. Vessel Operations is managed from Muskegon, Michigan with vessels based at Muskegon, Alpena, Bay City, Manitowoc and Monroe. Qualified personnel are required to safely and efficiently operate and maintain these research vessels and NOAA shore and supporting facilities. Vessel personnel assignments, and cruise requirements are detailed by the GLERL Marine Superintendent based upon mission requirements, and vessel maintenance.

column4: Killer whale sighting database, vessel activity monitoring, Soundwatch boater education, support for
column5: The first purpose of the project is to collect, compile and archive all sighting data of killer whales, particularly Southern Residents, as well as other cetacean species (e.g. humpback whales) from all available data sources throughout the entire year for each year of the contract and to maintain a centralized database of these data that is compatible for GIS analyses. The second purpose is to conduct on-water boater education and vessel data collection.  The third purpose is to support field studies on foraging, noise, and health of killer whales and other cetaceans species (e.g. Dtag and other similar projects).  The fourth purpose is to maintain an existing site and deploy new sites in The Whale Museum hydrophone network and develop outreach/education exhibits/programs.  A fifth purpose is to periodically review the museum’s long-term data sets on killer whale sightings, vessel activities and ambient/anthropogenic sound around kille

column5: The USCB seeks to acquire aggregated point-of-sale and/or scanner commercial data sets for the retail industry for special projects (such as retail geography). The USCB will work with the vendor on special projects that required aggregated company feeds of data at the NAICS level, and geographic detail. USCB and the vendor understand that the data requests must meet the requirements for quality, releasability, and disclosure for both organizations.The contractor will provide the USCB an updated inventory of companies that are available for the aggregated national and state groupings for the retail indicator or the special projects as well as the non-response company selection. This inventory will ensure accurate selection of companies for each project. column4: Economic Directorate Frame and Disclosure Research and Development
column5: The Contractor shall be capable of furnishing all required labor, material, and facilities to accomplish the services required herein. The scope of this work may be considered closely associated with inherently governmental functions. The scope of this work is critical to maintaining the USCB’s mission of being the leading provider of quality data about its people and economy by modernizing our data processing and security processes through innovative and exceedingly secure methods.This requirement is for research and modernization support in disclosure avoidance strategies and implementation, synthetic data projects and synthetic data validation, and the improvement of existing and new statistical products and services. The Contractor shall provide the technical management, expertise, and guidance for the tasks listed in the below task areas: 	Task 1-RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT		1.1 Disclosure Avoidance Research and Implementation

column5: PI: Meghan CroninTitle: USV Integrated within the Tropical Pacific Observing System (TPOS)Purpose: NOAA’s OAR/PMEL will utilize Uncrewed Marine Systems to make high resolution air-sea heat, momentum, and CO2 fluxes, in addition to multi-disciplinary (meteorological, oceanic physical, biogeochemical, and fish biomass) measurements and providing a unique solution for sparse sampling within the TPOS. This project will add days to the existing TPOS 2023 Saildrone mission, establish new Global-Ocean Uncrewed Surface Vehicles (USV’s) in priority areas of the northern hemisphere operating out of Hawaii and California, and make conduct a Pilot Study in the low-wind / high-current 95°W regime.

column5: PI(s): Dave Packer, Matthew PotiTitle: Gulf of Maine Seafloor MappingPurpose: NOAA’s NMFS/Northeast Fisheries Science Center and NOS/National Centers for Coastal Ocean Science will use Saildrones Uncrewed Marine System vehicle Voyager to acquire high-resolution multibeam bathymetry and backscatter data in the eastern part of the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management’s (BOEM) Gulf of Maine wind energy draft call area. The high-resolution seafloor mapping data will aid and improve BOEM’s decision-making process related to wind energy leasing and infrastructure siting areas and the Bureau’s assessment of potential impacts to sensitive hard-bottom benthic habitats.

column5: This request is for one (1) DriX uncrewed surface vehicle (USV) system instrumented with hydrographic and fisheries sonar survey systems, accessories including a launch and recovery system, spare parts, and vendor support for the operation of this system on NOAA ships with the option to purchase a future DriX USV. The USV is required to meet the needs of both the National Marine Fisheries Service for fisheries acoustic surveys and the National Ocean Service for shallow water bathymetric mapping

column5: PI: Dr. Jamison GoveTitle: Ecosystem-Based Fisheries Management in the Hawaiian IslandsPurpose: NOAA’s Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center will utilize the Liquid Robotics Wave Glider Uncrewed Marine System to survey phytoplankton biomass gradients and ocean conditions in the coastal waters (0 – 6 km) of the main Hawaiian Islands (MHI). The proposed work will occur alongside the upcoming Hawaiian Islands Cetacean and Ecosystem Assessment Survey (HICEAS) – a NOAA-led, multi-ship effort to assess cetacean distributions and ocean conditions throughout the Hawaiian Archipelago.

column4: Atmospheric Science and Technology Applications ASTA 2.0
column5: In general, analysis, development, and execution activities will be prescribed by lifecycle requirements and support the following mission focus areas: 1) providing timely access to global environmental data from satellites and other sources to promote, protect, and enhance the Nation's economy, security, environment, and quality of life; 2) providing data and information services, including space weather and Earth system monitoring; 3) performing data and information product stewardship and preservation; and 4) developing and disseminating information products, applications, tools, and models derived from observed data.

column4: NMR Console, Cryoplatform, and CryoProbe (5mm) for an Existing Bruker 700 MHz NMR
column5: The component upgrades (NMR console, Cryoprobe, Cryoplatform and Workstation) shall be delivered as one system unit that shall integrate with an existing NIST 700 MHz NMR (Bruker) and shall maintain capabilities of current accessories including a room temperature triple resonance probe, a  high-resolution magic angle (HRMAS) spinning probe, a 1 mm microprobe, and a SampleJet autosampler.

column5: The NOAA Office of Human Capital Services (OHCS) Retirement and Benefits Counseling Branch (RBCB) is a high touch counseling model that serves 12,000+ NOAA employees.  The HR delivery model work duties and responsibilities of the RBCB Specialist include but not limited to benefits counseling, counseling/transactional retirement related items such as HR Connect Retirement PAR actions, GRB case development, e-OPF case review, retirement packages for NFC/OPM, labor intensive multiple retirement estimates, FERCCA cases, disability cases, death cases including lump sum payments, and special project. The Retirement and Benefits Counseling Branch has a need to provide consultative services, training and guidance orally and in writing to active employees, potential retirees, management, HR staff, survivors, and others on the Federal retirement programs, benefits counseling, Government Retirement and Benefits (GRB) full platform, the retirem

column4: Office of Water Prediction Cloud Hydrologic Dissemination for Real-time Operations
column5: This task order will procure expertise in the development and implementation of operational cloud infrastructure in addition to hydrologic sciences, geospatial and data sciences, engineering services, software development, systems design and integration, and technical and programmatic support. This task order will include enhancements to the dissemination of flood inundation maps (FIM). The cloud infrastructure costs are out of scope of this PWS. The contractor shall work with NWS Office of Water Prediction (OWP) to propose enhancements and OWP will approve enhancements that are within cloud infrastructure budgets.

column5: The Quantum Sensors Group (QSG) at NIST requires an upgrade to specific components of a high-precision stage for controlling XYZ motion and rotation in a nanoscale x-ray tomography instrument. The stage will be operated inside an ultra-high vacuum chamber. This, along with the presence of other equipment in the chamber, constrain the size and shape of the total stage. The current stage consists of a coarse motion stage, a fine-motion stage, an interferometer mirror block, a rotation stage, a sample holder base, and a sample holder, contained within a metrology frame housing 6 interferometers. This package aims to replace components which are the main limitations to system performance, with optional specifications to replace other components limiting performance if they can be met at an acceptable price. The replacement of some or all this hardware will result in a significant advance in the capabilities of the x-ray tomography instrumen

column4: Analytic and Professional Support Services Indefinite Delivery/Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ)

column4: Lake Michigan Field Station Building 1 Renovations
column5: GLERL LMFS Building 1, a historical building built in 1905, is located adjacent to Lake Michigan and the Muskegon Channel. During Lake Michigan's record high lake levels, cracks in the basement floor allowed significant volumes of water to enter the building on a regular basis. This occurred regardless of storm or rain events, due to the site's high water table. The purpose of this project is to address the damage to the foundation to prevent flooding from occurring. Additional repairs to the exterior of the building are also included as optional line-items. Cmrently, there are four sump pumps located on the basement level that are used to pump the water out of the basement into the sewer or exterior of the building. When Lake Michigan water levels are elevated, pumping occurs continuously, but has suffered from clogging due to iron ochre in the water. Power outages have resulted in basement flooding in the past and a stand-by generator

column5: The Cooling Tower is the ultimate heat sink for the Reactor and auxiliary systems.  Cooling water flows through the reactor and then to Cooling Tower where heat is removed through the evaporative process.  Cooling Tower water is very corrosive to pipes and heat exchangers unless treated with a corrosion inhibitor.  Cooling Towers also need to be treated with a biocide to keep microbial organisms from propagating which could lead to fouling of heat exchangers and other important equipment.  Fouling will reduce the designed capacity of equipment leading to increased maintenance and possibly reduced Reactor operating time.  This acquisition is necessary to allow for the safe and efficient operation of the Nuclear Reactor associated with the NCNR. Failure to procure this product would cause the reactor to cease operation.

column4: Complete High Power Femtosecond Laser with Parametric Amplifier System
column5: 1.	Complete high power high repetition rate laser system including:a.	Near infrared ultrafast pump laser with >140 W, <500 femtosecond, >0.5 millijoule pulse energy output, user-selected from MHz to lower repetition rates.  Highest output power and user-controlled repetition rate from MHz down to single-shot preferred.b.	Optical Parametric Amplifier (OPA) pumped by the ultrafast laser to generate tunable output (within 600 nm to 900 nm and 1200 nm to 2500 nm ranges or larger) with <1 ps pulse duration and 5 W or greater output at the pump laser repetition rate.c.	Pump laser with M-squared TEMoo beam profile <1.2d.	All intermediary directing optics, beam baffles/dumps with laser/OPA cooling units supplied and tested for function and required specifications on sitee.	1 year or longer system warranteef.	Includes computer providing automatic software control of pump and OPA lasers for maximizing output power and wavelength tunin

column5: The WRC Security Path Improvements project seeks to upgrade an existing informal lawn walking path used for perimeter security patrols at the Western Regional Center (WRC) located in Seattle, Washington.  The project goal is to widen the trail to create a level walking/riding surface to reduce injuries to security personnel utilizing the path. The majority of the work is minor earthwork (grading and filling), small quantities of concrete work, and installation of a pre-engineered boardwalk system.

column5: An optical laser system that includes two mutually coherent, controllable, laser frequency comb sources, along with a common coherent continuous wave laser, within a maximum 2.75-liter size and 25 W power.  This effort focuses on the optics package, including the femtosecond laser, carrier-envelope-offset frequency generation, photodetection units, pump lasers and necessary temperature control/tuning. The system does not include the feedback control electronics. It is assumed the SWAP will be minimized by including the two-frequency comb optical subsystems and a compact continuous wave laser within the same physical package. While it is assumed erbium-doped fiber will be used, there should be evidence this fiber can be compatible with space operation.  If highly nonlinear fiber is used for carrier-envelope-offset detection, evidence must be provided that this fiber is also compatible with future space operation.

column5: The NIST Associates Information System (NAIS). Each year, NIST hosts more than 4,000 NISTAssociates (NAs), including foreign and domestic guest researchers, research associates, contractors, facility users, and other non-NIST employees. NAIS supports the process of bringing NAs to the NIST campus or allowing them access to NIST resources. NAIS is an internally developed system that automates the preparation, review, and approval of all NA agreements, extensions, and security forms required to bring associates to NIST. NAIS is an HTML5/JavaScript application front-end within a web-browser with a Java/Oracle database backend.  NIST seeks experienced support services for the operation of the NAIS help-desk, providing training to NAIS users, and developing testing scenarios.

column5: The easternmost TPOS line of surface moorings along 95oW has been extremely challenging to maintain due to the use of these moorings as Fish Aggregation Devices (“FADs”) by the international fishing fleet (Dempster and Taquet 2004), whereby vessels tie up to the mooring and perform a “slingshot” maneuver with the mooring under tension to isolate the aggregated fish for easier capture. As a consequence, the 95oW moorings, particularly in the equatorial band often have <50% data return, sometimes failing shortly after deployment. One possible solution is to replace the subsurface measurements of surface moorings with subsurface moorings, while relying on USVs for surface meteorological and oceanic measurements. The 2024 95oW Pilot Study, using FY24 funds, would test the performance of USV as a potential substitute for the moored surface meteorological observations along 95oW. Because this is a low-wind / high-current regime, it is likely

column5: Interpretation services (in-person, virtual/remote or hybrid), translation services, and virtual/remote simultaneous interpretation that includes a service platform with access to interpreters fluent in English and Spanish. Interpreters shall have experience presenting technical language related to topics including fisheries management, marine policy, and/or law enforcement and other similar or related topics in Spanish and English. Technical IT support for their platform required.

column5: The current sampling tower, located at MLO, was built in 1986 and stands 40m tall. It is an internal-climb, staircase-scaffolding, sampling tower and has platforms located every 6-feet. Additionally, four of the platforms are outfitted with quad receptacle power outlets. There is no known structural damage to the tower itself, however the guy line anchor points are rusted, and the tower is over 36-years old and does not meet current code requirements.

column4: NRMJ10002300614 Samoa Roof Removal and Replacement
column5: The current standing seam metal roof, installed in 2005, has deteriorated significantly in the last ~18-years.  NOAA has discovered that a major issue with this particular roofing design is that no vendors or materials are available on the island to do repair work on this specialized metal roof style.  99% of the buildings on the island with metal roofs use corrugated metal panel products.  As such, this solicitation encourages the use of roofing panels that are familiar to local contractors and possibly  available in local stores (limited supplies) for future repairs should any be needed.  Moving to a roofing style and material that is congruent with the other buildings on the island and one that will last as long as possible in the harsh tropical environment of American Samoa is highly-desirable.

column4: Lake Michigan Field Station Building 3 Construction
column5: GLERL is planning to renovate Building No. 03 (the Ecosystem Dynamics research laboratory) at the LMFS site. The renovations would require the removal and storage of government owned  equipment, removal of interior partitions, removal and disposal of the 4” concrete slab at grade, provision of a new structural slab, and fit-out of approximately 2,440 square feet of lab space and office space inclusive of architectural, mechanical, electrical  plumbing (MEP) and fire protection systems. column4: Single-tilt Windowed Gas Cell Heating TEM Specimen Holder System
column5: We seek to acquire a single-tilt windowed gas cell heating specimen holder that can be used in a Titan 80-300 kV environmental transmission electron microscope (ETEM).  This holder will be used to heat thin samples up to 1,000 °C in various gas environments (O2, N2, H2, CO, C2H2, C2H4, NH3, iron carbonyl, ferrocene, nickelocene, disilane, silane, etc.) at ranging from 5x10-4 Pa (3.75x10-6 Torr) to 2x105 Pa (1.5x103 Torr).

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), along with the Superconductive Electronics Group (672.06) develops and disseminates Josephson Voltage Standard (JVS) systems as a Standard Reference Instrument (SRI). As part of disseminating an SRI JVS system, we require a cryostat which can provide at least 300 mW of cooling power at temperatures below 4 K. This cryostat is required to cool packaged chips containing arrays of Josephson junctions, which are the key component of the JVS system. For the Josephson junctions to operate correctly, we also require that the cryostat has temperature fluctuations less than 5 mK peak-to-peak at 4 K near the chip, that it is compatible with our chip packages (both mechanically and electrically), that it is electrically isolated, and that it is magnetically shielded. We seek an Indefinite Delivery/Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) contract as we be purchasing a cryostat as needed when a SRI order

column4: Communications Technology Laboratory Program Support Services
column5: The Communications Technology Laboratory (CTL) performs research in broad areas that support the accelerated development, testing, and deployment of advanced communications technologies in support of both commercial and government applications. CTL focuses on developing precision instrumentation and creating test protocols, models, and simulation tools to enable a range of emerging wireless technologies. Driving much of  CTL’s work is a spectrum crunch in historically coveted wireless bandwidths. CTL’s research focus areas are: 1) core network technology, 2) public safety communications, 3) fundamental electromagnetic technologies and standards, 4) smart infrastructure and manufacturing, 5) next generation wireless systems, and 6) spectrum sharing and sensing. Within CTL there are five divisions, in addition to Headquarters Division: Public Safety Communications Research Division, Radio Frequency (RF) Technology Division, Wireless N

column4: GML Admin Program Support Services 3-yr Contract
column5: The Government intends to procure administrative personnel services to support the Global Monitoring Laboratory's (GML) mission with the global measurement of atmospheric trace species that are capable of forcing climate change through modification of the radiative balance of the atmosphere, and those that may cause depletion of the ozone layer.  GML has four atmospheric baseline observatories at remote locations and supports measurements at 55 other locations around the globe. These activities require a wide range of personnel skills ranging from technicians manning equipment in the field to Doctorate level scientists preeminent in their fields.

column5: FOR SUPPORT OF FIELD RESEARCH OF STELLER SEA LION SITES IN RUSSIA.  THERE ARE TWO ELEMENTS: FIRST ELEMENT IS TO INTERPRET, TRANSLATE, ANALYZE AND PRESENT RESULTS ORIGINATING FROM FIELD DATA COLLECTIONS (IN RUSSIA) AND CONTINUE COLLABORATIVE WORK IN WESTERN ALASKA. SECOND ELEMENT IS FOR AN ESTABLISHED RUSSIAN SPEAKING MARINE MAMMAL SCIENTITIST TO SERVE AS A LIAISON TO THE MML AND AFSC WITH RUSSIAN SCIENTISTS

column5: The ASOS Operations Monitoring Center provides 24/7/365 monitoring of nearly 1,000ASOS sites for the NWS, the FAA, the US Navy, and the US Army. The AOMCexecutes IT technical and administrative activities to support the operation andmaintenance of these sites and of the Local Area Networks (LAN). column5: Uncrewed Aircraft System (UAS) platform to provide positive identification of vessels subject to the Right Whale Ship Strike Reduction Rule traveling at speeds over 10 knots in Seasonal Management Areas during posted times and are not able to be identified and sanctioned via other sources (AIS, shore based collection platforms, USCG patrols). UAS also needed to provide assessment of sea state around vessels whose AIS transponder indicates they are speeding in violation of the RWSSRR in case the violator falsely claims sea state as the reason for speeding. Ideally, the UAS would also identify and note the location of any Right Whales observed while searching for RWSSRR violators.

column4: LONG RANGE / ROV LOBSTER GEAR OPERATIONS
column5: Use of a 100’ or larger offshore support vessel (OSV) with a Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) to provide imagery of lobster gear (traps and lines) in waters typically 20 to 200 nautical miles (NM) offshore of New England within depths up to 800ft. Law Enforcement personnel will request the hauling of suspected non-compliant gear aboard the vessel for inspection to ensure compliance with federal fisheries and protected resource regulations.  Video and still images taken from the ROV will be retained for documentary and or potential evidence per agency policy.

column4: Medium Range Lobster Gear Inspection Operations
column5: Use of a 55’ or larger Downeast lobster style vessel that by design is intended to efficiently and safely haul and reset commercial lobster gear in New England waters not to exceed 80 nautical miles (NM) from shore.  Law Enforcement (LE) personnel will provide an Agency owned and operated ROV and Side Scan Sonar (SSS) to collect imagery of lobster gear (traps and lines). LE personnel will request the hauling of suspected non-compliant gear aboard the vessel for inspection to ensure compliance with federal fisheries and protected resource regulations.  Video and still images will be retained for documentary and or potential evidence per agency policy.

column5: The purpose of the September 2023 MEP National Network Forum (MEPNN Forum) is to provide a venue for training, development, sharing best practice and networking for MEP Centers, NIST MEP staff and MEP stakeholders. The Foundation for Manufacturing Excellence (FORME) will organize programming informed by MEP Centers and NIST MEP subject matter experts. MEP Centers and NIST MEP staff will participate in training and workshops to share best practices and successful processes and programs to assist the MEP National Network’s mission of strengthening and empowering U.S. manufacturers, including the programming to encourage adoption of improved technologies, expanding supply chain mapping, pivoting manufactures to support critical industries, and to develop new products that respond to changing market needs. column5: The IOOS Surface Currents Program requires a service to compute, store, visualize, and publicly serve near real-time surface current velocity and wave data from the telemetry of its National Network of oceanographic high-frequency radars (HFRs).  This service is to include making these data and associated HFR diagnostic information available via a website accessible to the public.  Additional requirements for this service include:  ensuring its interoperability with other NOAA data repositories and information technology (IT) systems; performing quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC) of the telemetry in line with IOOS QA/QC of Real Time Oceanographic Data (QARTOD) standards; its ability to be readily configured to include or exclude data streams from individual HFR sensors based on feedback from those instruments' operators; and archiving lower-level files created by the HFR sensors (e.g., RangeSeries and radial velocities) along
column6: 518210 | Computing Infrastructure Providers, Data Processing, Web Hosting, and Related Services

column5: The Internet of Things (IoT) solutions are widely adopted and deployed across different industry sectors to solve specific business challenges to provide greater functional capabilities and produce telemetry data to provide analytics to increase productivity, reduce operation cost, improve quality of life, provide visibility, and make predictive decisions. IoT devices are becoming ubiquitous and enable the vertical markets to innovate at Internet scale and speed. These devices generate large amounts of data, connect directly to the Internet to transmit data and receive commands from large back-end data collection, analytics, and control systems in near real time. These added capabilities can introduce a large attack surface that can be minimized by adopting a risk management approach to reduce the impact to the system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.

column4: SITE Air Circuit Breaker Remote Racking Tool  PK 2
column5: NIST, Gaithersburg, MD, is a 60-year-old government research campus. As such, the facilities are in various stages of operability, and have multiple ages and manufactures of like systems repaired or replaced over those six decades. This action is to purchase code and regulatory safety equipment to protect the NIST employees while working on these electrical systems with equipment designed to address all design considerations, as well as providing maximum protection to the electrical workers from arc flash.

column4: Federally Funded Research and Development Center (FFRDC), Radio Frequency and Interference Monitoring System (RFIMS) Program Management Office (PMO) Professional Support Services
column5: Federally Funded Research and Development Center (FFRDC), Radio Frequency and Interference Monitoring System (RFIMS) Program Management Office (PMO) Professional Support Services.  The RFIMS PMO requirement is to strengthen its systems engineering and integration posture by pursuing technical expertise, guidance, and recommendations support from an FFRDC. The FFRDC will provide technical oversight, guidance, performance management, governance, change management, and monitoring of the development, integration, implementation, and Operation & Maintenance (O&M) and Sustainment of integrated solutions in order to support the RFIMS PMO’s acquisition objectives in a manner consistent with an existing RFIMS operations, maintenance, and sustainment contract.

column5: The overall objectives are to ensure that the satellite data produced by each of the NOAA operational sensors are of high quality, and meet product requirements and user needs.  This is achieved through extensive calibration/validation, scientific and technical research on sensor performance, characterization, anomaly resolution, re-calibration, and product validation by independent means. The work ensures that the quality of the data produced by NOAA meet or exceed international standards, is traceable to SI (International Systems of units), and best practices are followed in satellite instrument calibration/validation.  Additional objectives include supporting the radiative transfer model development and satellite data assimilation, and supporting the calibration/validation of emerging sensors based on emerging technologies such as SmallSat, radio occultation, and Internet of Things. column4: Radio Occultation Data Buy (RODB)-2 On-ramping RFP
column5: ¿The RODB-2 IDIQ has a provision set aside such that an "on-ramping" RFP will be issued on an annual basis that may lead to a new vendor being awarded an RODB-2 IDIQ contract; if a new vendor is awarded an IDIQ contract, that vendor will potentially share the life cycle cost (LCC) "pot" with the other vendors (PlanetiQ & Spire) of the 5-year contract or approximately $60M.    There will no new funds added to on-ramping RFP acquisitions.  A zero-dollar PR will be created. The first on-ramping opportunity will be in the 2QFY24 with an award projected in the 3QFY24

column5: Provide maintenance contracts for CBS related Oracle hardware Sun servers, workstations, and storage devices installed in the Fairmont datacenter. Support must be equivalent to Oracle/Sun Premium (Premier) Support Services. The terms of support are:24/7 technical support 	• Access to Oracle/Sun experts 	• Remote diagnostic tools 	• Lifetime Support for OS and virtualization software 	• Upgrade the OS on NOAA equipment when needed by NOAA 24/7 online resources 	• Oracle knowledgebase 	• Product documentation 	• Oracle support communities 	• Best practices 24/7 hardware service coverage 	• Two-hour Onsite Hardware Response¹ 	• Oracle Auto Service Request for Sun Systems 	• Experienced field engineers 	• OEM replacement parts 	• Field Change Orders (FCOs) Proactive support tools  	• Support alerts 	• Software update tools 	• Security resources     • Oracle Services Tools Bundle for Sun Syst

column4: Vessel Operations for Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory
column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL) operates a fleet of vessels ranging from 12’-85’ in length on the Great Lakes. Vessel Operations is managed from Muskegon, Michigan with vessels based at Muskegon, Alpena, Bay City, Manitowoc and Monroe. Qualified personnel are required to safely and efficiently operate and maintain these research vessels and NOAA shore and supporting facilities. Vessel personnel assignments, and cruise requirements are detailed by the GLERL Marine Superintendent based upon mission requirements, and vessel maintenance.  Mission support and technical positions have been added.

column5: NOAA requires the services of a company with extensive experience in risk reduction, including all aspects of preparedness, public safety, resilience, climate adaptation, and science and technology policy, to facilitate and support NOAA’s participation in intra-agency, interagency, academic, public-private, and intergovernmental activities.  These responsibilities include NOAA’s Senior Advisor for Coastal Inundation and Resilience serving in two concurrent leadership roles within the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy subcommittee framework.

column5: A coastal observation network with nodes on Lakes Michigan, Huron, and Erie, has been developed using real-time buoys as part of the Real-time Coastal Observation Network (ReCON), autonomous underwater vehicles (AUV), autonomous surface vehicles (ASV) and crewed and uncrewed air systems (UAS) to provide continuous observations of chemical, biological, and physical environmental parameters. The system currently supports projects addressing harmful algal bloom (HAB) detection, human health observations related to beach closures and drinking water processing concerns, rip current warnings, spill response, ice observations, ecosystem fire impact, and long-term ecosystem research. Observing system development relies on wireless broadband technology and network-based underwater hubs designed to allow expansion via satellite nodes. column5: NOAA Fisheries (NMFS) typically conducts a rapid appraisal of the social and economic impacts of these disaster events. Further, if the disaster declaration is filed under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (MSA) Section 315, NMFS is required to conduct an assessment within 60-days of the disaster declaration  depending upon the nature of the disaster. The NMFS may also conduct a second assessment to assess recovery at the six-month to one-year point.

column5: NOAA Office for Coastal Management (OCM) is looking to procure professional geospatial services, in support of various local, state, and regional coastal resource management needs. OCM’s primary areas of technological expertise include geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing, habitat mapping, data acquisition, hazards resilience, ecosystem services, and training. OCM has worked with state and other coastal resource managers, academia, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector to address coastal and ocean issues. Geospatial services are vital to OCM’s mission. The services are highly technical in nature and require specialized technical expertise that necessitates seamless, end-to-end capability. To meet such extensive and critical requirements, NOAA requires contractors to demonstrate full capability and capacity to simultaneously accomplish, and quickly react, to multiple tasks throughout the United States, it

column4: FY24 Third Party NAIS Code Identifier
column5: MEP requires a third-party independent resource to provide complete and accurate information about the manufacturing clients it serves.  MEP program performance is dependent on the timeliness and accuracy of establishment information provided by the vendor database.  The mission of MEP is to improve the competitiveness and productivity of U.S based manufacturers.  It is imperative that the program can validate that an establishment is a manufacturer and can be served by the program.  MEP uses the D&B database to serve in the capacity of an independent data source to support that validation.

column4: New Computer Based Trainings for the Current Population Survey
column5: The purpose of this call order is to obtain Contractor services for the technical writing and training activities of the Labor and Crime Surveys Branch. The mission of the branch is to provide the Census Bureau’s Regional Office staff with quality and timely procedural manuals, training guides and other reference materials to support the data collection activities for the Current Population Survey (CPS) and National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS).  Only CPS is covered by this task.

column4: Environmental Systems Research Institute - REsilience and ADaptation Information (READI)
column5: The Government intends to procure the REsilience and ADaptation Information (READI) Portal that is intended to be a centralized hub of information to aid in planning and implementing climate resilience in federally funded projects and programs with specific relevance to the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA). The READI Portal is meant to support a high-level assessment of project vulnerability based on exposure to climate-related hazards.

column4: MLO Emergency Paradise Helicopter Support Services
column5: C-SUITE PR# NR-MJ1000-23-01080, The government (NOAA) is requesting operational helicopter flight support to continue the critical long-term scientific mission of the MLO site until the road access is re-established.  Flight operations to MLO will begin after the eruption has subsided and State/County officials deem conditions safe for NOAA staff to return to the site.  It is assumed flight operations will be necessary until such time as road access to the facility can be re-established (timeline unknown).

column5: BigFix is one of many endpoint management tools in the NOAA IT Portfolio that supports IT asset inventory, cyber hygiene, patch management, and vulnerability remediation efforts.As a centralized solution, it allows NOAA BigFix operators to audit and manage all NOAA endpoints, regardless of their location (i.e., on premises, off premises, cloud, etc.).  BigFix is the authoritative source for NOAA meeting several FISMA reporting requirements, and it is one of the core tools sourced for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation (CDM) program - specifically within the Asset Management (AM) Capability.

column4: Software for Administration of Interlaboratory Comparisons and Quality Assurance Programs
column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology’s (NIST’s) Chemical Sciences Division (CSD) must acquire software capable of collecting, evaluating, and distributing data obtained as a part of numerous interlaboratory comparisons (ILSs) and quality assurance programs (QAPs). This software shall provide NIST the capability to deliver accurate and timely results to industrial and academic stakeholders and other Federal customers. The Contractor shall provide software and web-based tools (and associated support, including modifications of existing software and web-tools as requested) capable of collecting, evaluating, and distributing data obtained as a part of numerous interlaboratory comparisons (ILSs) and quality assurance programs (QAPs). Software must be capable of calculations that follow current ISO 13528 guidelines (https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:std:iso:13528:ed-3:v1:en) and be updated to reflect changes in the standard that m

column4: Salesforce Professional Services for NTIA Grants Portal (NGP - FY23 RC)
column5: This requirement is for professional services for the continued development and support of NTIA’s Grants Portal (NGP) being built on the Salesforce platform.  NGP is notionally comprised of two main aspects: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) and Grants Management.  CRM provides the underlying foundation of Accounts in terms of Grantees applying for grants and focuses on tracking NTIA staff engagement with stakeholders as well as with the grantees (emails, inquiries, speaking engagements, webinars attended, in-person events attended, etc.).  Grants Management is comprised of custom configured elements to support the life-cycle of a grant including application intake, review, post-award management and monitoring, and closeout. The contractor shall provide services to meet the requirements of NTIA.  This includes all personnel, materials, services, and management/supervision necessary to plan, schedule, coordinate, and assure effectiv

column5: Procure PRIVATE, Instructor-Led Virtual Python Training spanning FY23 and FY24 with a 12-month base and one 6-month Option period. Estimated Quantity of each course: Up to 7 units (7 classes with a minimum of 10 attendees per unit). The required courses are Introduction to Python Training, Advanced Python: Best Practices and Design Patterns, and Python Data Wrangling.  A 2023 Demographic Systems Division (DSD) strategic initiative has targeted Python to be the common programming language used throughout DSD in support of a technology shift at Census. Census IT is moving away from SAS to supporting Python. DSD’s strategic goal is to implement this Census IT directive by transitioning to Python in the near term.

column4: Implementation of Restoration Actions to reduce land-based inputs to Olowalu Reef, HI under BPA 1305M222ANCNP0003
column5: NOAA has prioritized the need to implement nature-based coastal protection and erosion-prevention solutions in the Olowalu and Ukumehame watersheds. The 939-acre Olowalu reef has been identified as one of the most essential reefs to protect on the island of Maui, Hawaii. Olowalu reef was declared an official Mission Blue Hope Spot in 2017, and research has shown that this large reef is an important source of larvae for other reefs in Maui Nui. The State of Hawaii Division of Aquatic Resources (DAR) has expressed an interest in developing effective management strategies for the area, and community support for management of the reef has grown in recent years. The site is also one of five priority areas identified for future in-water coral restoration in the State’s coral restoration action plan, developed by a multi-agency planning team to address climate change impacts, specifically coral bleaching.Poor water quality, with sediment as

column4: Cellular & Data Service for National Weather Service, Eastern Region
column5: The NWS ER seeks a contractor to provide cellular phone voice and data and text messaging services. The contractor shall offer multiple mobile devices and services with trade in options in accordance with the Blanket Purchase Agreement. The contractor shall give NWS ER access to a web portal to manage current devices and to purchase new devices in accordance with the Blanket Purchase Agreement (BPA). Furthermore, the contractor shall have a primary point of contact assigned to the NWS ER from the beginning to the end of the contract for customer service and support. Lastly, the contractor shall have the ability to identify areas of improvement and suggest better or improved products that will offer service and savings to the government.

column4: The purpose of this procurement is to purchase a new HVAC system for Marine Operations Center-Atlantic in support of OMAO/NOAA missions.
column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Office of Marine and AviationOperations (OMAO), Platform and Infrastructure Acquisition Division (PIAD) requiresConstruction services for the HVAC system retrofit, replacement, and upgrade in addition to the Hazardous Materials remediation and removal within the Marine Operations - Atlantic Facility (MOC-A). Services shall be complete in all respects and include labor, tools, materials, and equipment and sub contracts for a complete installation including any mechanical, electrical or plumbing work required. The MOC-A facility is located at 439 West York Street, Norfolk, VA 23510-1114. The requirement is for a Firm-Fixed-Price contract, with a total estimated value of $1,200,000.00.

All new and existing security system infrastructure for the PACS, video management systems, all network devices including hardware, secure configurations, software, licensing, system maintenance, wiring, ancillary devices (such as network equipment and other monitoring devices), Cyberlocks, and remediation of identified system deficiencies of these systems shall be covered under this IDIQ.

column4: Support for Research, Standardization, and development of Reference Materials for Multi-Party Threshold Cryptography, Privacy-Enhancing Cryptography and Interoperable Randomness Beacons
column5: Provide support to NIST through participation in the development of Privacy Enhancing Cryptography (PEC), including the areas of secure multiparty computation and zero-knowledge proofs.  The task will include support for the standardization of mutli-party threshold schemes (MPTC) and activities of interest to the Interoperable Randomness Beacons, related to the use of trusted randomness.  The task includes research in scope with the Circuit Complexity project, including the compilation or development of circuits of interest.   Support will be provided in the development and revision of NISTIRs and NIST SPs as well as recommendation reports related to PEC, interoperable randomness beacons and multi-party threshold schemes

column4: RESEARCH DATA PUBLICATION + PUBLIC ACCESS SYSTEM - OAR DATA DISSEMINATION
column5: In compliance with the government policy and law which requires open data access to federally funded scientific research, the NIST Material Measurement Laboratory, Office of Data Informatics (MML/ODI) in collaboration with Office of Information Systems Management (OISM) initiated and oversees the design and development of a NIST data publication and public data dissemination system to provide researchers and organizations outside NIST open access to the highly valued data products and services provided by NIST.   The MML/ODI Division is also undertaking a comprehensive effort to incorporate modernization and next-generation NIST Standards Reference Data into the NIST data dissemination web-serviced portal.   These efforts are performed in coordination with Associate Directory of Laboratory Programs (ADLP)/Special Programs Office (SPO) and the Information Services Office (ISO) for the production support of NIST’s Open Access for Research

column5: National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) needs to develop Standardized Position Descriptions(SPD) and receive support on the classification of unique position descriptions as new hiringinitiatives arise across NMFS for CAPS positions. This would involve an assessment andreview by a group of individuals that are designated by the agency as subject matter experts(SMEs) for the various positions within NMFS. These reviews will determine the number ofstandardized position descriptions to be developed, along with making recommendations forassigning employees into the new positions descriptions.

The data must meet the following key requirements: (i) wireline and wireless speed test data; (ii) including all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and U.S Territories;; (iii) include standard measurement details, such as key indicators to measure network performance and location, details about the test, and information about signal and device (iv) exclude Personally Identifiable Information (PII); (v) NTIA must have the ability to access and ingest the raw underlying data into our systems; and (iv) vendor must adequately document their data collection methodology.  Any additional data or analysis tools that can be provided should be listed with any subsequent cost but are not required.

column4: SIFT Servers for NOAA National Weather Service Tsunami Warning Centers
column5: The Government intends to procure replacement SIFT servers for the Tsunami Warning Centers in Hawaii and Alaska to support Tsunami forecasting operations. SIFT (Short term Inundation Forecasting for Tsunami) is the forecasting system accepted for operations at the U.S. Tsunami Warning Centers. This requirement will be competed amongst the contract holders of the Department of Commerce Strategic Sourcing network equipment contracts.

column5: LEO and OSPO require Scientific Services support, Engineering Services, Analytical, and Program Operation Management Support. These FTEs will be supporting Non-IT requirements. LEO Ground Segment Project is organized into eight functional nodes. The eight nodes are: the Space/Ground Communications Node, the Ground Network Node, the Management and Operations Node, the Data Processing Node, the CGS Support Node, the Simulation Node, the Calibration/Validation (Cal/Val) Node, and the Field Terminal Support (FTS) Node. Tasking include but not limited to: Program Science Proving Ground, Risk Reduction, and Requirements, External and Internal Science Communications, Science-related engineering, General support in planning and executing for LEO and OSPO, Acquisition Support Team and Property Contact, Personal Property and Logistics Support (Supply Technicians) and Engineering Support.

column4: Harbor Seal Predation on Puget Sound Salmonds
column5: This project will focus on two representative estuaries in Puget Sound to quantify the magnitude of harbor seal predation on juvenile, resident, and adult life stages of steelhead and Chinook, chum, coho, and pink salmon as they migrate through ecologically diverse and seasonally variable estuarine habitats.
