column5: Commercial Data Housing Files Statement of Work:	Background: The U.S. Census Bureau (USCB) conducts research and production work using administrative records data to enhance numerous programs and products. The Census Bureau enters into agreements with data providers, including federal, state, and private entities, to acquire data files. These data are used to support planning and conducting future decennial censuses, current surveys such as the American Community Survey (ACS), and other Census Bureau demographic and economic research and production work. The Census Bureau will use the data acquired in the contract to continue to carry out the aforementioned production work that is underway as well as continue our research to find new uses for the data we obtain.In support of the USCB’s mission, the Economic Reimbursable Surveys Division (ERD) is responsible for acquiring and maintaining a broad range of administrative

column4: Government Retirement and Benefits Software - Full Access Platform
column5: NIST requires a commercial software that is web-based with capabilities to obtain data automatically from the National Finance Center (NFC) or any third party without agency intervention to accurately compute various complex estimates needed in assisting employees with their retirement decisions to include FERCCA. The purpose of the Retirement/Benefits software is to automatically calculate all types of Federal employee retirement benefits, provide retirement case management, auto-populate forms, and provide metrics and reports for employee profiles under CSRS, CSRS Offset, FERS, TSP, and Social Security Administration programs.  This intuitive system would also allow employees to run their own retirement estimates, high-3 years of salary, and TSP withdrawals, benefiting all of the NIST staff, as well as alleviating the workload from the OHRM staff so they can focus on additional strategic and operational priorities.  This platform woul

column4: SWO Engineering Support task order under ProTech-Satellite
column5: To accomplish its mission, the NESDIS Office of Space Weather Observations (SWO) is looking for on-site contract-based support to provide necessary space weather engineering expertise. The contractor will assist SWO in the following engineering activities: Requirements analysis, concept studies, and early development tasks as part of flight project development; design and formulation of new space weather missions under SWO's purview on behalf of the government; integration, test, and post-launch checkout of NOAA ground assets supporting SWO missions; integration, test, launch and on-orbit checkout of NOAA space assets; and mission operations, sustainment, and closeout of SWO project missions.

column5: The proposed requirement is for two new multi-tasking 5-Axis Mill Turning Centers. It is also required to pack, remove, and trade in seven milling machines. The required equipment will allow for full 5 axis machining and turning with C1 and C2-Axis positioning of 0.0001°, sensor driven feedback, separate tool access, models on the controller with 3-D assist, A.I tool suggestion, smooth machining operation and facilitate reuse of 20 years of specialized FTO technician specific existing program and project work.

column4: PROTECTED SPECIES DIVISION (PSD) RESEARCH SUPPORT SERVICES
column5: Support services are required to provide field research, analyses, and outreach to support PSD operations. In general the contractor shall conduct and support research needed for the management of protected species in support of NMFS mandates and responsibilities. Support includes, but is not limited to, collection of information on protected species populations, data analyses and development of improved analytical techniques, studies of marine acoustics insofar as sound affects or is created by protected species, investigation of techniques and management actions to reduce the impacts of human activities, and economic analyses to improve our understanding of the social consequences of actions affecting protected species. Contractors shall also support outreach and education efforts to deliver the results of PSD research to various audiences.

column4: ACS Data and Digital Test Decks
column5: The purpose of this contract is to provide paper materials and data sets to the American Community Survey (ACS) to achieve improved testing capabilities. The objective of the Government’s testing is to ensure that a change to an ACS form or question(s) does not impact data analysis and/or data products.  To achieve improved testing capabilities of paper data capture, the Government requires test materials that simulate or consist of real handwriting in order to simulate real-life survey response conditions.

column5: A sensitive spectrometer is needed for far-field and scanning probe imaging and spectroscopy (electroluminescence and photoluminescence) at SWIR wavelengths.  The spectrometer will be used to characterize emission from devices and defects in cryogenically cooled samples, down to the single entity level, such as an individual color center complex in a host crystal.  The low light levels encountered require high efficiency in both wavelength discrimination and photon detection processes.  The low energy per photon necessitates attention to dark current and read noise.

column4: Vector Network Analyzer with Noise Figure Measurement
column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) requires a Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) that has the capacity to assess noise figure. This equipment will be utilized to analyze both the S-parameter and noise figures of a range of active and passive electronics components in the process of advancing high-frequency characterization for cryo-electronics and devices. Additionally, it will aid in sustaining the ongoing cryo-electronics program for quantum information science, high-performance computing, and cryogenic sensor applications.

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Pressure and Vacuum Group requires high speed multi-channel high speed lock-in-servo to perform laser locking to photonic sensors or offset locking to photonic sensors.  This tool is critical for thermodynamic metrology, photonic thermometry, and optical pressure metrology.

column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Office of the Deputy Under Secretary (ODUS) is holding a training summit for senior executives called the Senior Executive Service (SES) Summit. This training summit aims to strengthen the leaders of NOAA to use and communicate NOAA science and services.  NOAA’s SES Summits are an opportunity to bring the approximate 120-150 members of NOAA’s SES cadre together (including ST and SL members) for collective training and collaborative learning opportunities.

column5: The UMSD requires Contractor support services to provide for training services and operation assistance for the current fleet of USV; and future USVs added to the fleet. The support services include: (1) Developing and training NOAA personnel for operation of DriX USV. The training includes, Supervisor Level I, II, III; Surveyor Level and Instructor level. Online training classes and Remote Operations Center (ROC) (2) Provide support for the operations, logistics and maintenance for DriX fleet. The vendor needs to be an approved Drix/Exail supplier.

column5: The NWS COOP Program collects daily Maximum and Minimum Temperature data from approximately 3,500 COOP stations.  The Maximum/Minimum Temperature System (MMTS) requires a direct cable connection from the outdoor MMTS thermistor to the indoor Nimbus display unit.  The average usage rate for 'MMTS Cable' is approximately 15,000 feet per year.   The brand of cable for form, fit, function is Belden Inc., model #9802 cable.

column4: FY24 Perform Emergency Power Generators Preventative Maintenance at WFOs and RDAs in the Southern Region.
column5: This Preventative Maintenance (PM) Agreement is for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Weather Service (NWS) Southern Region Headquarters (SRH). The Emergency Power Generators under this agreement provide emergency power to Weather Forecast Offices (WFO) and Weather Surveillance Radar (WSR) sites. Locations are listed below. This PM Agreement is for a term of one year with an additional four-year option upon acceptance. This will cover multiple locations and shall be accomplished annually or every 250 hours of operation by a certified EPG Maintenance Contractor.

column5: The NIST Center for Neutron Research (NCNR) is part of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in Gaithersburg, Maryland. Its activities focus on providing neutron measurement capabilities to the U.S. research community.It is a national center for research using thermal and cold neutrons, offering its instrumentation for use by all qualified applicants. Many of its instruments rely on intense beams of cold neutrons emanating from an advanced liquid hydrogen moderator. Our mission is threefold: To operate the NCNR safely as a cost-effective national resource. To conduct a broad program of research using neutron techniques, and to develop and apply new neutron measurement techniques.   To operate the NCNR as a national resource for researchers from industry, university, and other government agencies. This acquisition is necessary to allow for the safe and efficient operation of the Nuclear Reactor associated

column4: Collection of Additional Invasive Testing Data for Chaplain Towers South
column5: The objective of this task order is to manage any movement, non-destructive testing and/or other non-invasive evaluations of building evidentiary debris for the preparation of concrete and steel sample extractions; the collection and examination of concrete cores and steel reinforcing bar samples extracted from CTS physical evidence specimens; and the collection of laboratory test data for the concrete cores and reinforcing bar samples. The CTS physical evidence, housed in primary evidence facilities in Miami, FL, will be furnished to the Contractor by NIST. The data collected by the Contractor will be used by the NCST CTS investigation team to evaluate the properties and conditions of the CTS Condominium at the time of collapse. A technical report summarizing the extraction location, extraction date and time, condition, chain of custody, and other pertinent information related to the concrete cores and reinforcing bar samples will be d

column4: Customized version of Laser Thermal's Steady-State Thermoreflectance in Fiber (SSTR-F)
column5: Laser Thermal’s patented and commercialized fiber-optic instrument design, Steady-State Thermoreflectance in Fiber (SSTR-F), measures the thermal conductivity of thin film and multilayer materials. In TR measurements, a top surface metal transducer film is typically deposited to monitor the sample temperature changes. The transducer layer significantly enhances the TR signal and reduces the signal to noise ratio. The pump and probe laser wavelengths are selected to maximize pump absorption, minimize probe absorption, and to maximize the coefficient of TR for the transducer material. Laser Thermal’s commercial SSTR-F instrument uses pump and probe wavelengths that are optimized for aluminum transducers; our work requires gold transducers which are also compatible with our existing FDTR instrumentation. Laser Thermal is uniquely capable of designing and building NIST a customized version of their commercial SSTR-F thermal property measure

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), along with the Superconductive Electronics Group (672.06), develops and disseminates Josephson Voltage Standard (JVS) systems as a primary reference for the SI volt. As part of the verification of the SRI JVS system at the user location, we require a travelling cryostat which can provide at least 100 mW of cooling power at temperatures below 4 K. This cryostat is required to cool packaged chips containing arrays of Josephson junctions, which are the key component of the JVS system. For the Josephson junctions to operate correctly, we also require that the cryostat has temperature fluctuations less than 20 mK peak-to-peak at 4 K near the chip, that it is compatible with our chip packages (both mechanically and electrically), that it is electrically isolated, and that it is magnetically shielded. The system is required to be assembled in a rack compatible with ground/air shipping

column4: NOAA Human Resources review of services
column5: In the fall of 2015, The Department of Commerce (DOC) began its transition to an Enterprise Services (ES) delivery model for select Human Resources, Financial Management, Information Technology, and Acquisitions service towers. ES was established in part, to create efficiencies with centralized operations and reduce costs for the Department. The ES Human Resources Tower of service was established to provide DOCbureaus, such as NOAA, with personnel action processing and to improve some processes with enabling technology.  At the time ES was established, NOAA’s Office of Human Capital Services (OHCS, as it was later renamed) assessed our non-transactional human capital services and adopted a new business model consisting of human resources (HR) generalists and Centers of Excellence (COEs).  The business model created Business Advisors (HR generalists) who were assigned specific NOAA Line and Staff offices to provide HR consultation se

column4: Technical Writing Support for HM, NWIRP, and HF
column5: The purpose of this contract is to provide the Engineering Laboratory (EL) at NIST with contractor services to provide technical writing support, including graphic visualization, layout, proofreading, and editing support (in both English and Spanish) for the Hurricane Maria National Construction Safety Team (NCST) investigation and National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program (NWIRP) study, including aspects of Hurricane Fiona.  The contractor shall assist NIST in creating professional grade reports and other materials documenting the studies, findings, and recommendations, as described below. Requirements similar to the tasks associated with Hurricane Maria NCST investigation and NWIRP study will be included as optional requirements, which may or may not be exercised, for the Champlain Towers South NCST investigation and the Hurricane Ian NWIRP study.

column5: This Statement of Work is to provide a meeting planner to assist the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Marine Fisheries Advisory Committee (MAFAC) in obtaining the necessary support services to include meeting/event management logistics support and technical and visual management support services. The meeting planner shall demonstrate extensive experience in providing meeting support services as well as identify staff with knowledgeable background and qualifications in meeting or conference planning services.The MAFAC typically holds two in-person meetings per year to discuss living marine resource and marine fisheries management issues and priorities to advise the Secretary. Meetings are approximately three days in length and are attended by MAFAC members NOAA and NMFS senior leadership and staff and the public. column4: NF-FS7300-24-MM004 PHASE ONE AERIAL SYSTEM FOR CCEP
column5: The AFSC/MML conducts pinniped stock assessments to meet the mandates of the Marine Mammal Protection Act. Pinniped stock assessments require data collection methods that rely on fixed-wing, crewed aerial surveys to ensure coverage of the entire west coast region. The current survey system is antiquated and can no longer be updated to interface with new technology that makes processing of the data inefficient. Other pinniped fixed-wing, crewed aerial survey programs have adopted an integrated camera and computer system that produces high quality, georeferenced imagery that can be easily processed through automated programs. With these modernized systems, the surveys only require a single observer, or just the pilot that operates the camera user interface for pre-programmed flight transects, and better quality electronics allow for flying at higher altitudes and faster speeds, which decreases the hazards associated with crewed aerial sur

column5: This is a new firm fixed price contract to purchase, from the Hexagon Manufacturing Intelligence Company, an ultra-high accuracy Leitz Infinity (12.10.7) Coordinate Measuring Machine (CMM) with the LSP-S4 probe. CMMs are measuring instruments that can contact and measure points on manufactured parts. These systems measure the size and shape of parts to ensure parts made by one manufacturer fit parts made by another.

column5: The Transformational Networks and Services Group (TNSG) in the Communications Technology Laboratory, Smart Connected Systems Division, at the National Institute of Standards and Technologies (NIST) develops foundational network science, network measurement science, engineering, standards, and best practices to support industrial transformations critical to national priorities such as industrial automation and smart transportation. TNSG’s research efforts include fifth and sixth generation (5G/6G) core networks, edge and distributed AI (Artificial Intelligence) and their applications to networking, AI-based autonomous networking, optical and quantum networking, cloud computing, information-centric networks, and automated driving.The purpose of this requirement is to obtain contractor services to develop networking and measurement technologies for 5G/6G networks and applications, build 5G/6G core network testbed, create test methods and

column4: CHIPS R&D: RF Metrology for HF Transistor Models, Focus Load pull D-band
column5: Abstract Advanced semiconductor technology has led to continuous performance improvements in transistors. However, many iterations are needed to obtain optimal performance and the yield and reproducibility is incredibly poor. Furthermore, US chip makers are ill-equipped with legacy measurement techniques and underperforming models. We propose a robust path to develop and verify high-frequency transistor models:  1) new on-wafer standards and calibration, 2) precision noise measurements for transistor quality assurance, 3) improved characterizations, 4) optimal models tailored to a given technology, and 5) transistor model verification across frequency with key performance indicators.  Problem Statement(s)  Due to the challenges of high-frequency measurements, that includes inaccuracy in on-wafer calibration and a lack of instrumentation for transistor characterization, models are currently extracted from low-frequency measur

column4: CHIPS R&D: Critical Dimension Small Angle X-ray Scattering (CDSAXS)
column5: Abstract In-line dimensional metrology is critical to high yields in semiconductor manufacturing. The industry currently uses optical scatterometry for process control to monitor feature size and shape. As devices get smaller and more 3D, optical scatterometry is reaching fundamental limits. NIST has developed a method called Critical Dimension Small Angle X-ray Scattering (CDSAXS) for next generation dimensional metrology. The NIST-developed method has been commercialized and NIST plays a critical role in supporting end users and equipment manufacturers in the application of CDSAXS. CDSAXS is used for measuring contact holes in 3D-NAND memory arrays and is being developed for gate-all-around (GAA) nanosheet transistors and through-silicon vias.  Problem Statement(s)  The semiconductor industry is in need of new in-line dimensional metrology methods to measure the size and shape of nanoscale structures such as gate-all-aroun

column4: CHIPS R&D: NanoMicro ThermoMechanics, Environmental AFM
column5: Abstract Some of the manufacturing difficulties encountered by the heterogeneous integration of modular chips in system-in-package are due to thermal management and mechanical incompatibilities among the various interfaces and building blocks of the package. This project will provide indentation and scanning probe-based measurements for the process-induced alterations of the thermo-mechanical properties of materials and structures used in advanced packages. Building on our decades-long expertise in nanoscale to microscale mechanical property measurements on microelectronic materials, we will improve and deliver measurement methodologies and data to industry to enhance their predictive manufacturing. column4: CHIPS R&D: XAFS and Diffraction, XRD Upgrade
column5: Abstract Non-Destructive Semiconductor Structure Function and Process Optimization for future Microelectronics Manufacturing at the NIST NSLS-II Beamline for XAFS and Diffraction. This project relies on the existing NIST Synchrotron beamline for X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) and our CRADA with IBM for the improvement of these measurement capabilities utilizing state of the art of the art IBM semiconductor samples working directly with IBM researchers stationed at NIST BLs and others.  The proposed equipment enhancements will substantially increase sample throughput and sensitivity.  Driving the ability to probe deeper semiconductor device interfaces, a broader set of element/matrix combinations, and nanoscale probes of device stacks.  These enhanced capabilities over the course of the next 3 years are then broadly available to the US Semiconductor Industry via preferentially allocated beam time at

column4: CHIPS R&D: High speed metrology for magnetoelectronic devices and models, Magnet
column5: Abstract Ferromagnet-based microelectronic devices play an increasingly important role within the semiconductor ecosystem. Magnetic RAM (MRAM) is already replacing embedded Flash memory and is being considered for last-level cache in processors. We will address the critical industry need for precise measurement of magnetic material and device parameters (Heisenberg exchange, magnetic relaxation rate, perpendicular anisotropy, attempt frequency) by expanding measurement methods first developed at NIST. These measurements and methods will enable industry to improve models to significantly accelerate the magnetic device development process.  Problem Statement(s)   The U.S. Semiconductor industry is integrating ferromagnet-based microelectronic devices such as magnetic RAM (MRAM) into existing silicon-based technologies. MRAM has much shorter write times and higher write endurance than the embedded Flash currently used.

column4: CHIPS R&D: GaN SiC Defects, High Transmission Energy Resolution
column5: Abstract  Advanced bonding and integration physically bring together components, devices, and materials produced separately. There are strong economic and functionality incentives to use this approach at a range of physical sizes from 300 mm to 1 mm, and electrical and photonic interconnect size ranges from 100 µm to 1 µm. Bonding relies on getting two surfaces to adhere. Pretreatment of the surfaces is known empirically to be critical for successful bonding.  However, known good processes (KGPs) are typically developed through trial and error. NIST can apply unique analytical and metrological capabilities to develop a scientific understanding of bonding processes. This general understanding may provide a predictive framework for rapid KGP development which directly impact chiplet manufacturing. Problem Statement(s)  The most important part of any bonding process is getting the surfaces to stick. While the physical propertie

column4: CHIPS R&D: Nanoscale, Element-Specific X-ray Imaging, Electron Column
column5: AbstractWe propose to develop an x-ray computed tomography (CT) instrument capable of 3D, element-sensitive imaging from the micrometer to the nanometer-scale and over integrated circuit (IC) chip-relevant scan areas. This represents new capabilities for characterizing subsurface features for both manufacturing and security applications, improving detection of physical defects, material contamination, and malicious tampering. NIST is uniquely positioned to carry out this project, leveraging expertise and equipment developed during the IARPA Rapid Analysis of Various Emerging Nanoelectronics (RAVEN) Program. We propose to further develop a proof-of-concept demonstrated during the RAVEN program, extending 3D metrology capabilities beyond those of current state-of-the-art x-ray CT systems. We aim to transfer these capabilities to industry such that it can become a standard tool available for 3D IC diagnostics.Problem Statement(s)Indu

column5: Abstract Semiconductor measurement labs struggle to measure Scattering (S-) parameters—how electrical signals travels through and reflect off—of integrated circuits, which impedes the adoption of new enabling technology. The key ideas in this proposal are to (1) distribute, to industry, validated research grade on-wafer S-parameter calibration kits that include optimized integrated circuits on standard reference materials (SRMs) and (2) work with manufacturers to integrate NIST models into commercial calibration software. After one year, we will evaluate success with a round robin, establishing a new standard reference instrument (SRI) in coordination with an industry consortium. Problem Statement(s)  ‘calnet.nist.gov’ squarely addresses grand challenge “Standardizing New Materials, Processes, and Equipment for Microelectronics” (GC6). The project also significantly contributes to “Enabling metrology for integrating componen

column4: NWFSC Lower Trophic Level Indicator Support
column5: Assist with the collection, analysis, and handling of data to support the development of indicators of lower trophic levels. Primary duties include collecting, extracting, and sequencing environmental DNA samples; maintaining and operating an automated imaging-in-flow cytometer and related hardware infrastructure; data pipeline development; database development and management; documenting workflows and preparing summary text, tables, and figures. May require participation in fisheries surveys and spending days at sea.

column4: RF Arbitrary Waveform Generator - Indefinite Duration - Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ)
column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), along with the Superconductive Electronics Group (672.06) provides Josephson Arbitrary Waveform Synthesizer (JAWS) systems as a standard reference instrument (SRI).  As part of disseminating an SRI JAWS system, we require one (1) Arbitrary Waveform Generator that will provide fast, arbitrarily shaped pulses at a speed >15 Gpulse/second to arrays of Josephson junctions which then generate standard voltages. We propose to purchase an instrument that operates at faster than 60 Gigasamples/sec with greater than 20 GHz analog bandwidth, at least 8 bit resolution, at least 10 Gigasamples of memory, and internal FIR filter that is identical to that used in prototype SRI JAWS systems at NIST. This instrument uses proprietary features (DAC design, etc.) that will work with existing hardware used in our experimental system.  Furthermore, items from other manufacturers cannot be used witho

column4: Thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) and Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC)
column5: Purchasing 2 instruments from the same vendor. A thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) continuously measures mass while the temperature of a sample is changed over time.  Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) is a thermoanalytical technique in which the difference in the amount of heat required to increase the temperature of a sample and reference is measured as a function of temperature. Samples can be polymer and concrete and will provide critical information to many of the ongoing and future IMG research projects.

column4: CHIPS R&D: RF Metrology for HF Transistor Models, VDI Extenders
column5: The proposed strategy to improve high-frequency transistor models entirely falls under the Grand Challenge 4 “Modeling/Simulating Semiconductor Materials, Designs, and Components”. Accurate sets of transistor characterization will immediately benefit the high-frequency semiconductor foundries as they will be able to verify their existing models and to re-adjust or extract new models based on the proposed model-extraction strategy. Development of improved techniques for precision noise measurements on amplifiers and transistors solves the challenges currently encountered in quality assurance of transistor fabrication. We envision a 4-year project to develop more accurate transistor circuit models based on improved instrument calibration and characterization of microwave parameters. These models and measurement techniques will be directly disseminated to semiconductor companies. We currently collaborate with governmental agencies (AFRL, D

column4: CHIPS R&D: Atom Probe Tomography with EUV
column5: Advanced Metrology for Future Microelectronics Manufacturing.  Value: Physical properties characterization for surfaces, buried features, interfaces, and devices with increased resolution, sensitivity, accuracy, and throughput. Rapid high-resolution techniques for characterizing defects and impurities.  NIST is purchasing one of the first commercial deep ultraviolet atom prob microscopes through Phase I Shared Use Equipment. In the first 12-18 months of that instrument being online, we expect to provide comparative data analysis on specimens provided by our industry collaborators and in a short time produce Best Practice Guides for optimizing measurements on this new commercial APT system. These will immediately improve the repeatability, reliability, and decrease the uncertainty of APT experiments performed on currently available commercial instruments. column4: CHIPS R&D: Nanocalorimetry for Semiconductors and Semiconductor Process Metrology, LDV
column5: The Nanocalorimetry for Semiconductors project addresses the second grand challenge - Advanced Metrology for Future Microelectronics Manufacturing by accelerating the development of thermal properties measurement capabilities for small scale materials and devices; a measurement gap that has repeatedly been identified as a critical limitation for improving overall energy efficiency of memory and logic all the way to improvements for 3D integration of dies and chiplets.  Once the initial planned work to improve the measurement system is accomplished, this project could also provide data for the Grand Challenge IV - Modeling and Simulating Semiconductor Materials, Designs, and Components.  The first objective is to develop a robust simultaneous sample mass measurement capability to be able to report accurate specific values (which require the ability to quantify the quantity of material being tested). column4: QuoData licenses for PROLab Plus and PROLab_HUB with customizations
column5: NIST currently coordinates a number of interlaboratory studies (ILSs) and quality assurance programs (QAPs) that participants use to identify and understand community-wide measurement challenges, improve the accuracy of their measurements, and demonstrate an effort to comply with various regulations. These programs offer the opportunity for laboratories to assess their in-house measurements, and participation in a quality assurance program in conjunction with the use of reference materials has been shown to improve the comparability and precision of data over time. CSD intends to utilize PROLab, PROLab_Hub, and any future developed or improved QuoData data visualization tools to conduct and analyze data from ILSs and QAPs.

column4: CHIPS R&D: Strain Measurement, Direct Electron EBSD
column5: Abstract Mechanical strain impacts the performance of semiconductor devices. Manufacturing processes must be carefully controlled for strain to achieve high yielding and high-performance products.  However, measuring strain in nanoscale devices remains a metrology challenge for manufacturers. Different techniques (EBSD, TKD, 4-D STEM, Raman, µXRD, etc.) are either commercially available or under development to address this need, with NIST making significant contributions to these methods. As geometric complexity and importance of strain continues to increase, we intend to continue advancing these techniques, improving their accuracy, and supply new reference materials to ensure capabilities for future-generation devices.

column4: CHIPS R&D: Nanoscale, Element-Specific X-ray Imaging, Precision Sample Positioning Stage
column5: AbstractWe propose to develop an x-ray computed tomography (CT) instrument capable of 3D, element-sensitive imaging from the micrometer to the nanometer-scale and over integrated circuit (IC) chip-relevant scan areas. This represents new capabilities for characterizing subsurface features for both manufacturing and security applications, improving detection of physical defects, material contamination, and malicious tampering. NIST is uniquely positioned to carry out this project, leveraging expertise and equipment developed during the IARPA Rapid Analysis of Various Emerging Nanoelectronics (RAVEN) Program. We propose to further develop a proof-of-concept demonstrated during the RAVEN program, extending 3D metrology capabilities beyond those of current state-of-the-art x-ray CT systems. We aim to transfer these capabilities to industry such that it can become a standard tool available for 3D IC diagnostics.Problem Statement(s)In

column4: CHIPS R&D: Metrology for Integration of New Magnetic Materials, Vibrating Sample Magnetometer
column5: Abstract This program will develop the metrology, materials, and methods needed to integrate magnetic components with semiconductor materials, thereby reducing the size and improving the functionality of electromagnetic (EM) systems for communications, radar, and advanced computation. EM systems use magnetic components such as inductors, isolators, and adaptive filters, but these are currently bulky and difficult to integrate with microelectronic circuitry. This limits the utility of the magnetic components. Reducing the size, weight, and energy dissipation of magnetic components and integrating them onto semiconductor chips and into packaging will enable broader exploitation of magnetic materials and provide new mechanisms for the control and manipulation of EM signals. column4: CHIPS R&D: Accurate Mapping of Thermal Properties,
column5: Abstract Precise measurements of thermal properties at the nanoscale are needed for engineering of both advanced and heterogeneously integrated electronic devices but are currently unattainable. We will radically advance thermal properties metrology by developing a new tool for mapping thermal conductivity (¿), interfacial thermal conductance (G) and chemical composition at the nanoscale, with high throughput (20¿ms/pixel) and high precision (¿¿¿<5%, ¿G¿<10%), concurrently. Thermal properties will be obtained by measuring the transient photothermal expansion of a sample with high spatial (˜10 nm) and temporal (˜4¿ns) resolutions using NIST-made optomechanical AFM probes and wide-bandwidth detection. Synergistically, we will develop a far-field, super-resolution microscope capable of mapping thermal properties with ˜ 500 nm resolution, ultrahigh throughput ˜ 5 µs/pixel (˜ 24 million times faster than the state-of-the-art) and with de

column4: CHIPS R&D: Accurate Mapping of Thermal Properties, AFM
column5: Abstract Precise measurements of thermal properties at the nanoscale are needed for engineering of both advanced and heterogeneously integrated electronic devices but are currently unattainable. We will radically advance thermal properties metrology by developing a new tool for mapping thermal conductivity (¿), interfacial thermal conductance (G) and chemical composition at the nanoscale, with high throughput (20¿ms/pixel) and high precision (¿¿¿<5%, ¿G¿<10%), concurrently. Thermal properties will be obtained by measuring the transient photothermal expansion of a sample with high spatial (˜10 nm) and temporal (˜4¿ns) resolutions using NIST-made optomechanical AFM probes and wide-bandwidth detection. Synergistically, we will develop a far-field, super-resolution microscope capable of mapping thermal properties with ˜ 500 nm resolution, ultrahigh throughput ˜ 5 µs/pixel (˜ 24 million times faster than the state-of-the-art) and with de

column4: CHIPS R&D: RF Metrology for HF Transistor Models, Foundry fabrication Teledyne
column5: Abstract Advanced semiconductor technology has led to continuous performance improvements in transistors. However, many iterations are needed to obtain optimal performance and the yield and reproducibility is incredibly poor. Furthermore, US chip makers are ill-equipped with legacy measurement techniques and underperforming models. We propose a robust path to develop and verify high-frequency transistor models:  1) new on-wafer standards and calibration, 2) precision noise measurements for transistor quality assurance, 3) improved characterizations, 4) optimal models tailored to a given technology, and 5) transistor model verification across frequency with key performance indicators. Problem Statement(s)  Due to the challenges of high-frequency measurements, that includes inaccuracy in on-wafer calibration and a lack of instrumentation for transistor characterization, models are currently extracted from low-frequency measure

column4: CHIPS R&D: AWACKSM, Dual-Comb IR Laser
column5: Abstract Advanced packaging involves increasingly challenging requirements for heterogeneous integration and 3D chiplet integration. Challenges such as fine pitch interconnects (<10 mm pitch), finer lines/spaces, and an increasing number of distribution layers will require intensive engineering design to minimize warpage and maximize thermal performance while retaining or improving reliability in harsh conditions over the long-term life of the package.  To be successful, research advances must address the most challenging materials and interfaces in the package, such as underfill materials, organic substrates, and molding and potting epoxies.  Accurate material property measurements as a function of processing conditions, such as cure time, temperature, and pressure, are critical to inform predictive tools used to analyze how process tool requirements affect the warpage of 3D integrated assemblies and packages.  This effort will als

column4: CHIPS R&D: RF Channel Propagation Measurements & Modeling, High Speed Digitizer
column5: Abstract An accurate characterization of how the wireless signal propagates through different environments and frequency bands, is key to developing RF communications circuits. This measurement need has been identified by the research community and documented in many publications and roadmaps. This project aims at developing novel measurements and instruments for characterizing RF propagation and developing models and datasets for use in modeling and simulation of RF communications circuits.  Problem Statement The need for propagation measurements to develop and evaluate communication circuits has been identified by the research community and well documented in many publications and roadmaps [1][2][3]. column4: CHIPS R&D: Time-resolved emission microscopy, Large cryostat from array measurements
column5: Abstract Time-resolved-emission microscopy (TREM) is a workhorse of semiconductor circuit evaluation. However, as transistor dimensions and power-supply voltages have been reduced, transistor emission has become fainter and signals from multiple transistors are convoluted. There is a strong desire from the Electronic Device Failure Analysis Society, documented in their recent roadmap, for improvements in TREM for circuit analysis of advanced technology nodes; improving the sensitivity and number of pixels in the sensor arrays are primary objectives for meeting these needs. With this project we will achieve these goals by tailoring NIST’s single-photon detectors to this purpose and scaling up these sensors to the megapixel level. Problem Statement(s)  When a new integrated circuit is fabricated, it is necessary to measure the chip with microscopy techniques such as photon emission microscopy, which look at infrared photons em

column4: CHIPS R&D: Molecular dynamics simulation GAAFETs, Computer nodes (Muzny, Chris/Sasha)
column5: Abstract We will use NIST’s computational resources and theoretical expertise to assess heat transport within nanometers of the heat sources created by CMOS conductive channels. Extensive molecular dynamics simulations will be used to quantify heat transport, including boundary scattering. Combined with measurements, we will elucidate the physics behind nanoscale heat transport and provide data toward refining the existing finite-element models and ultimately laying foundation for enhanced transistor-level heat transport in the next-generation semiconductor devices. If successful, this project will shift the paradigm of nanoscale heat management from trial-and-error to knowledge-based engineering. Problem Statement(s)  Thermal efficiency of semiconductor devices is pivotal to their operation and performance, especially now that the dimensions of transistor features are rapidly shrinking to the nanoscale. A significant knowle

column4: CHIPS R&D: EUV Photoresists, RSoXS Camera Upgrade, RSoXS Camera Upgrade
column5: Abstract The semiconductor industry continues to push for smaller features, more integration, and increased yield. New photoresist chemistries and advances in extreme ultraviolet lithography are enabling this trend. However, this is inhibited by a lack of measurements describing heterogeneities in chemistry that contribute to the quality of photoresist patterns at these smaller dimensions. This includes fundamental questions into how the EUV exposure changes the resist chemistry and its spatial extent, and the underlying mechanisms that produce those changes. Our proposed NIST team will characterize the properties of advanced lithographic materials, measure nanoscale chemical distributions, and study the patterning process in situ. column4: CHIPS R&D: CalNet, Frequency Extender Heads
column5: Abstract Semiconductor measurement labs struggle to measure Scattering (S-) parameters—how electrical signals travels through and reflect off—of integrated circuits, which impedes the adoption of new enabling technology. The key ideas in this proposal are to (1) distribute, to industry, validated research grade on-wafer S-parameter calibration kits that include optimized integrated circuits on standard reference materials (SRMs) and (2) work with manufacturers to integrate NIST models into commercial calibration software. After one year, we will evaluate success with a round robin, establishing a new standard reference instrument (SRI) in coordination with an industry consortium. Problem Statement(s)  ‘calnet.nist.gov’ squarely addresses grand challenge “Standardizing New Materials, Processes, and Equipment for Microelectronics” (GC6). column4: This purpose of this requirement is to continue developing software to execute NIST-developed algorithms that address data analysis and uncertainty quantification questions in diagnostics, forensics,
column5: This purpose of this requirement is to continue developing software to execute NIST-developed algorithms that address data analysis and uncertainty quantification questions in diagnostics, forensics, and artificial intelligence.  Often the underlying data is generated by standard metrology equipment (e.g. fluorimeters and mass spectrum analyzers).  Thus, a key component of this work entails writing and testing software code that can interface with common data formats exported by commercial and in-house instruments.

column5: This will be a Task Order under the existing Cybersecurity And Privacy Support Services (CAPSS) IDIQ contract. column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) promotes the U.S. economy and public welfare by providing technical leadership for the nation’s measurement and standards infrastructure. NIST’s responsibilities include the development of management, administrative, technical, and physical standards and guidelines for the cost-effective security and privacy of other than national security-related information in Federal information systems.   In advancing its mission objectives, NIST must validate cryptographic modules, cryptographic algorithms, as well as ensure independent labs are meeting performance criteria.  The Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP) was established by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Communications Security Establishment (CSE) of the Government of Canada in July 1995.The  (CMVP) is a joint American and Canadian security accreditation program for cryptog

column4: This is a forecast for FE
column5: This IRA-funded project will transform habitat conservation, climate-based risk assessment, and recovery science by providing better tools and information for science and management partners. The project addresses three related aspects of habitat conservation – population recovery mandates incorporated into NOAA Fisheries’ Viable Salmon Populations framework. These aspects include 1) better decision support tools, 2) a suite of standardized and easily usable indicators of habitat conservation trends, population status, and threats to recovery, and 3) community engagement through networking, education, and transparent data sharing. Contractors will work with several NWFSC scientists to address these aspects.

column5: Currently we have 1 VFD per tower, each tower has 4 motors.  This creates a situation where losing or servicing of one of the VFDs could take down 25% of the cooling plant capacity. This project will Add 4 VFDs and replace 4 existing, for a total of 8, to control 2 motor on each VFD.

column5: The current sampling tower, located at MLO, was built in 1986 and stands 40m tall. It is an internal-climb, staircase-scaffolding, sampling tower and has platforms located every 6-feet. Additionally, four of the platforms are outfitted with quad receptacle power outlets. There is no known structural damage to the tower itself, however the guy line anchor points are rusted, and the tower is over 36-years old and does not meet current code requirements.

column5: The U. S. Department of Commerce (DoC) Office of Financial Management (OFM) produces useful, accurate and timely consolidated financial statements and other financial reports and analyses for the Department. It provides useful and timely guidance and assistance to Departmental components in the implementation of federal financial management standards, policies and procedures.  It is a top priority goal for the OFM to maintain compliance with federal financial management reporting requirements and maintain a clean audit opinion. Federal agencies are statutorily required to produce an annual agency Performance and Accountability Report (PAR) or an Annual Financial Report (AFR).  Agencies are also required to prepare and submit interim financial statements to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).  OMB’s Circular No. A-136, Financial Reporting Requirements, provides guidance and requirements for federal financial reporting.OFM

column4: Corporate Aircraft Service Program for AOC King Air N68RF/FM-21
column5: Corporate Aircraft Service Program (CASP) is a warranty plan that provides replacement and repairs of all avionics parts under the entire Collins Avionics suite in AOC King Air N68RF/FM-21. The current CASP subscription expires March 2024. This requirement is to continue services which have historically shown to be a beneficial program that saves costs to the government when avionics components become inoperative. This requirement is to renew services through 2026.

column5: The Government intends to procure contracted assistance to support its DC-QNET-PQNI Project.The Transformational Networks and Services in the Smart Connected Systems Division in the Communications Technology Laboratory (CTL) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) is doing research in the development of novel network control and management systems capable of automating the configuring, monitoring, and troubleshooting of complex networks as well as their deployment and operation. column5: Provide Mail Centers large commercial postage meter machines that are able to weigh, mark postage for payment to USPS, along with the associated software, maintenance, and rental contract for each mailing system. Due to the volume of mail processed at the Regional Offices and NPC, each office is required to always have a functional mailing system which includes ongoing maintenance and support for daily operations.USCB intends to acquire the meter machines on a lease-to-own basis, though options to ether strictly lease or purchase the meter machines outright will be considered. Other components of the system including the postage meter head, software, installation and maintenance will have a period of performance.The system must be compatible with United States Postal Service regulations.

column4: Optical Clock for Contribution to Official U.S. Time
column5: NIST seeks an integrated optical atomic clock suitable for inclusion in the NIST system of atomic clocks which generates UTC(NIST), NIST’s realization of Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). NIST intends to contribute observations of the clock to Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM; International Bureau of Weights and Measures) as part of NIST’s BIPM’s ongoing key comparison CCTF-K001.UTC. NIST intends for the clock’s observations to contribute to synthesis of the international atomic time scale (TAI). NIST intends to use the optical- and microwave signal outputs of the new clock to expand NIST’s calibration services’ support of ultra-high stability- and optical-frequency sources. NIST intends to use the clock’s short-term stability as a resource in the synthesis of low-noise microwave signals for ongoing laboratory atomic spectroscopy efforts, and as a transfer oscillator in the measurement of other optical atomic clocks.

column4: Modeling hotspots of seabird-fisheries interactions and bycatch in Northeast U.S. Fisheries
column5: The overall goal of this project is to improve understanding of bycatch of seabirds, particularly Great Shearwaters (Ardenna gravis) and Northern Gannets (Morus bassanus), in northeastern U.S. and Atlantic Canada commercial fisheries, and to work cooperatively with partners to identify and encourage voluntary adoption of effective bycatch reduction strategies within targeted fisheries.

column4: Purchase of a dilution refrigerator for quantum memory
column5: Quantum memory is an important device for quantum communication and networks, especially for quantum repeater and quantum network nodes.  SiC micro-cavity enhanced quantum memory based on Er:YSO is a promising solution for high efficient quantum memory at telecom wavelength. Currently, in collaboration with University of Chicago (U. Chicago) and Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), the quantum communication and networking (QuCaN) project at the Information Technology Laboratory (ITL) of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) is developing such a quantum memory. We plan to deploy on the NIST Gaithersburg (NG-QNet) and DC area (DC-QNET) quantum network testbeds at NIST Gaithersburg campus.

column5: Analytical support is needed to produce various online reports of fishing activity and fishing indicators, such as (1) fishing activity within offshore wind lease areas; (2) indicators of annual social and economic performance of commercial fishing businesses, and (3) key indicators for Northeastern fishing communities, among others. Support includes the generation of statistical tables, charts and graphs, and web query tools. Meeting support may also be necessary, including participant travel costs (lodging, airfare, per diem, etc., for both domestic and international travel); meeting facilities (meeting rooms, AV equipment, etc.); and hotel blocks.

column4: Polatis Series 6000 Ultra Secure grade Switches
column5: The purpose of this acquisition is to obtain a number of Polatis Series 6000 Ultra Secure grade All-Optical Switches, manufactured by Huber+Suhner. The switches will be used to route single and entangled photons around a quantum network testbed on the NIST campus and across the DC-region. The switch will be integrated into the existing infrastructure of the QN testbed at NIST and the infrastructure across the region. The network uses Polatis switches to manage the routing of quantum signals and a unique, NIST built Quantum Network Control Plane has been especially developed to manage this process. This control plane is written specifically for Polatis switches. For this reason, we require a BRAND NAME ONLY switch (manufacturer part number Polatis S-OST-08x08-LA1-HMHNS and S-OST-64x64-LA1-HMWNS) – although we do not specify the source from which this item can be purchased.

column4: Contract manufacturing of a CHO expressed monoclonal antibody (cNISTmAb)
column5: The Biomolecular Structure and Function (BSF) group intends to develop a monoclonal antibody expressed from the NISTCHO reference cell line as a NIST Reference Material (NIST RM).  The material is intended to be highly representative of CHO-expressed monoclonal antibodies used as biopharmaceuticals.  This reference material is planned to be a companion molecule to both the NISTmAb (RM 8671) monoclonal antibody reference material (reference product) and the NISTCHO (RM 8675) cell line reference material (non-originator expressing cell line).   As such, the BSF group intends to contract the manufacturing of a monoclonal antibody expressed from the NISTCHO cell to an organization capable of performing such manufacture and characterization to include key features of GMP manufacturing to enable a comparable production process and similar quality attributes (commonly referred to as “GMP-like”).  This material will be released with quantitativ

column4: Mass Spectrometer with two UHPLC systems
column5: One (1) mass spectrometer and two (2) UHPLC systems, inclusive of FOB destination delivery, installation, warranty, training, and option line items. Mass spectrometer must be a hybrid mass spectrometer that combines quadrupole, linear ion trap, and Orbitrap mass analyzers and features CID, HCD, ETD, and UVPD fragmentation techniques. UHPLC systems must be compatible with mass spectrometer and must meet needs for certification of NIST RMs, HDX-MS, and oligonucleotide analysis activities.

column4: Dilution refrigerator for hybrid electronic and photonics quantum development
column5: A closed-cycle measurement cryostat capable cooling and measuring samples at <15 mK with a cooling power at least 300 uW at 100 mK. The cryostat shall have (48) low frequency measurement lines (twisted pair), (9) power supply and control lines, and (8) high frequency lines with SMA connectors.  A superconducting magnet capable of producing >5 T with a bore of >3” shall be included. The system shall have automated controls for cooling down and warming up, including all valve operations during the introduction, condensation, circulation, collection and safing of the 3He/4He. Customer shall supply the required 3He. Calibrated thermometry for accurate monitoring of the temperatures at all stage shall be supplied and heaters for controlling measurement temperatures and facilitating expedited warm shall be provided.

column5: "Brief: Replacement for the current automotive scale fuel cell test stand.Justification:  The current automotive scale fuel cell test stand that is no longer supported by General Motors rendering in nearly useless. We can obtain support for the new stand from the test stand manufacturer.  Costs for the new stand will be recovered through amortized fuel cell testing fees.  Since many companies want to use the test stand we will continue to bring additional funding to NIST through it's service in the NIST neutron imaging program.  This test stand is vital to maintain NIST's role as an international leader in automotive fuel cell research.  Maintaining this capability at NIST will allow the NIST neutron imaging team to bring in additional funding to NIST."

column4: Widely Tunable Single-Frequency Continuous wave Visible Laser System
column5: The Government intends to procure a Widely Tunable, Single-Frequency, Continuous wave, Visible Laser System compatible with the extensive existing spectroscopic infrastructure to support the Quantum Measurement Division in the Physical Measurement Laboratoryin order to support development of novel spectroscopic measurement techniques to probe key physicochemical properties of advanced quantum materials (i.e., 2D…) that will enable future technologies to move past conventional digital computing. The new system must meet the following specifications. (1) continuous wave laser with at least 200 milliwatts power output at all wavelengths and gap free tunability from 450-525 nanometers (nm) and 540-650 nm (the gap around the pump wavelength of 532 nm can be smaller than 15 nm) (2) Simultaneous gap-free tunable output from 900-1050 nm and 1080-1300 nm (the gap around the doubled pump wavelength of 2064 nm can be smaller than 30 nm)(3) o

column5: STAR requires renewal of McIDAS software and maintenance support. McIDAS (Man computer Interactive Data Access System) is a software package that is used with geophysical data, such as satellite and radar imagery, in-situ observational reports, and gridded numerical forecasts. Other functions include acquiring, displaying (static and time-lapse), analyzing, interpreting, and managing the data. Designed to handle large amounts of data in a convenient manner, the McIDAS packages are a vast resource of image-processing and applications programs and subroutines. Many scientific programs within STAR, and elsewhere in NOAA, currently use McIDAS on a daily bases for their scientific data analysis. It is a very capable and relatively economical system, and it would cost hundreds of thousands of dollars and man-hours to migrate to a different system, if one was even available which could do all that McIDAS can.

column5: The NEFSC requires alternative technologies to maintain survey data collection and to observe ecosystem changes within wind energy installations.  NEFSC scallop surveys currently produce precise and accurate data using a standardized dredge and a towed optical system known as HabCam (habitat camera). An AUV with a payload that matches HabCam’s imaging and sensing capabilities will both help mitigate impacts of wind development on surveys and broaden data collection for fishery management. The stereo images and accompanying metadata need to be collected at least every 10 m on a given track line.  Images are best taken within 1-2.5 m of the seabed (although a certain percentage of images can be tolerated up to 5m above the seabed where it is necessary for navigation).

column5: NIST Hosted: A NIST conference where NIST [or authorized designated individual(s) at NIST's direction (i.e., through a contractor)] has control of most aspects of conference planning and execution (proceed to Step 3).NIST Co-Hosted: A joint effort between NIST and another entity, public or private, to conduct a conference, which is of benefit to each entity. It is evidenced by an execution of a MOU setting for the purpose, responsibilities and basis for the joint effort. In some circumstances, NIST will employ a contractor as an “event planner” to manage the logistics of the event but the contractor is not considered a “co-host.” (proceed to Step 3) Click here to learn more about MOU on our Directives FAQ page.NIST Sponsorship/Exhibitor Space: Sponsorship is a means of supporting a conference by providing funds in exchange for something of value, such as brand exposure, access to attendee data, or speaking opportunities. column4: Connex Move from one location to another
column5: The purpose is to move an 8 x 20 shipping container from one location to another (see SOW for map and locations below) during the week of April 22-26, 2024. The modified shipping container has approximately 500 lbs of contents, including a bard 2-ton hvac unit. All contents of the container will be secured before removal. The target schedule for the work is April 2024, dependent upon weather or scheduling factors. NOAA personnel should be on site while the work is being performed at both locations, so work must be scheduled to accommodate the time frame when NOAA personnel can provide access to the site. NOAA seeks to remove / decommission existing shipping container at the existing/old tower at Beech Island, South Carolina (ASR 619083), and move it to the new tower location at Barnwell, South Carolina (ASR 1059177).

column4: WxCoder and SIS Replacement Systems, Operations & Maintenance (June 10, 2024- June 9, 2025)
column5: An Additional Work Statement (AWS) is required by the National Weather Service (NWS) to fund Operations and Maintenance of the WxCoder and Station Information System (SIS) metadata replacement system. The WxCoder will continue to provide the NWS Cooperative Observer Program (COOP) the means to report daily weather observations from nearly 8,000 locations in the USA, Pacific, and the Caribbean.  The O&M for the WxCoder system will now include the additional function to maintain the new  metadata and maintenance system for all the COOP sites. This new function derives from the Station Information System (SIS) replacement system.

column4: WCDAS 14.2 Meters Antenna L/S Band Feed
column5: FY25  The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service (NESDIS), Office of Satellite and Product Operations (OSPO) mission is to sustain current NESDIS capabilities, and to enable future capabilities. NOAA/NESDIS’s overarching goal is to migrate to an Enterprise ground system solution and eliminate mission specific designs. A needed step in this migration is the upgrade or replacement of the Wallops Command Data Acquisition Station (WCDAS) Polar 14.2-meter antenna L/S band RF Feed Assembly. In order to integrate the USSF mission and still retain NOAA’s legacy mission requirements,  The current L/S band feed assembly had been degraded will require a technology refresh or complete replacement.

column5: EV Reach (Goverlan) is an on-premises client management software utilized by NOAA5006 IT support team designed for medium to large enterprises for remote control, active directory management, global configuration change management, and reporting within our NOAA5006 Windows and MAC OS IT Infrastructure. EV Reach (Goverlan) Enterprise and Professional edition include unlimited endpoints. This allows NOAA5006 IT support team to continue to achieve a hands-on posture to cover all workstations across our NOAA5006 enterprise; with all of employee’s teleworking without the use of a VPN.

column5: The Government intends to procure a new cryogen-free superconducting magnet system to support the Fundamental Electrical Measurements Group, Quantum Measurements Division, Physical Measurement Laboratory, NIST in order to support the development of graphene-based AC QHR devices, modernizing the capabilities for dissemination of the ohm and farad, and promote quantum impedance standard for distribution to other national metrology institutes and primary resistance laboratories. This project involves developing a digital impedance bridge to calibrate fused-silica capacitors with a combined standard uncertainty less than 0.05 ppm in reference to quantum Hall resistance. Graphene-based QHR standard has been attested for DC calibration. A cryogen-free superconducting magnet system with the following specifications:The system/parts shall meet or exceed the minimum requirements identified below. All items must be new. Used or remanufact

column5: The Transformational Networks and Services Group (TNSG) in the Smart Connected Systems Division, Communications Technology Laboratory at the National Institute of Standards and Technologies (NIST) develops foundational network science, network measurement science, standards, and best practices to support the transformation of industries critical to national priorities such as industrial automation and smart transportation. TNSG’s research efforts include fifth and sixth generation (5G/6G) core networks, edge and distributed AI (Artificial Intelligence) and their applications to networking, AI-based autonomous networking, optical and quantum networking, cloud computing, information-centric networks, and automated driving.The purpose of this requirement is to obtain contractor services to develop AI and ML (machine learning) techniques (including models and algorithms) for supporting 5G/6G networks, quantum networks, and applications

column4: This action is to procure Vaisala Model 221030 USB-M12 Service Cable (USB PC ConnectionCable 8 pin M12, RS-485, Powering; Comparative with HMP155) 150 each mission critical capabili
column5: This action is to procure Vaisala Model 221030 USB-M12 Service Cable (USB PC ConnectionCable 8 pin M12, RS-485, Powering; Comparative with HMP155) to provide technicians themission critical capability of connecting to and configuring the Vaisala HMP155E Temperatureand Relative Humidity Sensor, as well as, maintaining the sensor in the field. The VaisalaModel 221030 USB-M12 Service Cable is the only cable that is both compatible and reliable.with the Vaisala Model HMP155E Temperature and Relative Humidity Sensor. The VaisalaModel HMP155E Temperature and Relative Humidity Sensor. The Vaisala HMP155E Sensorprovides mission critical temperature and relative humidity measurements to the NWS via theAutomated Surface Observing System (ASOS). ASOS serves as the nation’s primary surface.weather observing network. ASOS is designed to support weather forecast activities, aviation.operations and the needs of the meteorological,

column5: The OHCS serves as the human resources office for NOAA providing the full range of human resource activities and partnership with management to carry out NOAA’s mission.  The OHCS human capital centers of excellence, provide technical assistance to NOAA’s line and staff offices in the areas of workforce analytics, performance culture and learning, employee and labor relations, policy, strategic recruitment, and executive resources.  This contract will expand the services offer by the Centers of Excellence; adding bench strength to the organization.NOAA is seeking to establish a blanket purchase agreement for services from a variety of vendors who will support NOAA’s OHCS in providing services to our employees.

column4: Keysight N1000A DCA-X Mainframe including LOJ and PTB with N1046A 2-port 100 GHz  remote sampling head
column5: II. ScopeThe goal of this contract is to supply a sampling oscilloscope with a 100 GHz bandwidth for use in developing new ultra-fast metrology of thermal transport at the nanoscale. The contractor shall deliver the specified system inclusive of FOB Destination delivery, installation, and 3 year warranty.III.	MINIMUM REQUIREMENTSThe Contractor shall provide a system that meets all technical specifications identified below. All items must be new.  Used or remanufactured equipment will not be considered for award. Experimental, prototype, or custom items will not be considered.  The use of “gray market” components are not authorized for sale in the U.S. by the Contractor is not acceptable.   All line items shall be shipped in the original manufacturer’s packaging and include all original documentation and software, when applicable.

column4: Time Domain Thermoreflectance (TDTR) instrument that will incorporate a multiple color output Asynchronous Optical Sampling System (ASOPS) for high-speed time-resolved pump-probe experiments.
column5: NIST is constructing a custom Time Domain Thermoreflectance (TDTR) instrument that will incorporate a multiple color output Asynchronous Optical Sampling System (ASOPS) for high-speed time-resolved pump-probe experiments. The ASOPS includes the lasers, complete ASOPS synchronization electronics, and pulse trigger and RF synthesizer for tuning the difference frequency. In TDTR, a modulated ultrafast laser "pump" pulse heats the sample and a delayed pulsed "probe" beam interrogates the thermal properties of thin film or multilayered materials as a function of the probe delay time. The ASOPS TDTR instrument will enable NIST to uniquely measure the in situ thermal properties of thin film and multilayer materials in wide bandgap power electronics materials, packaging materials, and integrated chip components, directly supporting our CHIPS Project: Thermoreflectance Thermal Property Measurements. This CHIPS project supports Grand Challenge 4:

column4: Procedure Strategy and Procedure Writer's Guide
column5: The overall objective of this task is to set the groundwork and structure for the NCNR Procedure Hierarchy Strategy. The need for a procedure strategy has been defined by the Independent Nuclear Consultant assessment results and outcomes from the Integrated Safety Culture Monitoring Panels held in Dec 2023 and March 2024.  Each of these inputs has a procedures aspect, and while other direct activities may address the specific recommendation and ISCMP Item, the team must be mindful of the procedure aspects while developing the strategy.

column4: Portfolio, Program and Projects with professional support services (PMO)
column5: The Office of Dissemination performs portfolio management of the operation, and maintenance of NWS IT systems, infrastructure, and services throughout the Nation. It is responsible for dissemination of NWS weather, water, and climate data and information between Weather Forecast Offices, to local Emergency Managers, and to the public. The Office must also manage budget planning, milestone integration and provision of internal controls for the entire Portfolio.

column4: Alaska Region disposal for Mc Grath untis 108 and B6
column5: Contractor to handle the concrete foundation stem walls, firewalls, and stairs in a manner that, to the best extent practicable, separates the painted concrete from the non-painted concrete for disposal purposes.  Once separated, the contractor shall dispose of the painted concrete out of the State of Alaska.  The unpainted concrete may be disposed of in the local landfill.  The Contractor shall remove the concrete pad that supported the former NWS Warehouse Storage Building and a vertical metal pole that protrudes from the ground at the site of the Mc Grath and Yakutat.

column4: liquid chromatography quadrupole time of flight mass spectrometry system
column5: •	The system shall include a benchtop QTOF mass spectrometer and an ultra-high pressure liquid chromatography (UHPLC) system.•	The system shall include a PC-based data system/instrument controller including operating system, instrument control/data acquisition/data analysis software, and monitor.•	The system shall include an electrospray ionization (ESI) source and have the ability to interface with a direct analysis in real time (DART) source.•	The benchtop system, including UHPLC and MS, must weigh less than 600 pounds. •	The system must fit on a standard laboratory bench (30 inches deep), with the inlet of the mass spectrometer facing outwards towards the operator. The system must be no higher than 50 inches tall.•	The ionization sources shall be capable of supporting ESI and a DART sources and shall have an option for upgrading/adding atmospheric pressure photo-ionization (APPI).o	The ionization sources shall be able to

column4: Subscription services to a semiconductor supply chain database
column5: CPO requires five (5) licenses to access a web portal that shall provide industry data, expertise, and analysis on a range of semiconductor companies that illuminate areas of risk. The service shall include information on the industry's market participants, key management and personnel, investors, supply chains, business partnerships, and US government contracts. The web portal shall allow data searches. CPO should be able to independently conduct all searches and, the data results should be immediately accessible, and all data searches conducted are considered confidential and should be treated as such.

column5: The Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) Cyber Security Division (CSD) are requesting a renewal of their Red Hat software, maintenance and support. NOAA has been purchasing, maintaining, and using Red Hat software for many years. This software has been integrated into distributed systems across all NOAA offices. Therefore, NOAA requires Red Hat software maintenance (to include technical support, software updates, and software upgrades) to be purchased annually in order to meet its operational and mission requirements.

column5: Charter of a vessel and crew to recover and deploy a moored surface buoy approximately 300 nautical miles southeast of Tokyo, Japan, in the vicinity of 32.3°N, 144.6°E. In addition, the vessel will also deploy and/or recover other moorings or assets specific to that year's mission plan including but not limited to mooring remnants, drifters/floats, gliders and test moorings for additional equipment. This replaces forecast ID 30173.

column4: Modifications to NIST SST1 Beamline for New NEXAFS Station at NSLS II
column5: 1) Removal of current M5 mirror to increase overall beamline optical efficiency (one less reflection) and increase useable beamline floor space, and simplifying beamline optics.2) Reconfigure and relocate current DM8 diagnostic module on its own dedicated base frame.3) Confirm that DM8 Io mesh and screens can image M4C and M4D dithered beams.4) Replace current NEXAFS experimental station with a new design based upon a chamber similar to the Hard X-ray Photoemission Spectroscopy (HAXPES) station on SST-2.5) Introduce a new Support Stand for the 10,000-element detector, compatible with the existing soft x-ray optical path in conjunction with the new NEXAFS experimental chamber.These changes need to occur while ensuring that: all new components fit perfectly to atolerance within a few microns; the downstream beam path is unperturbed in normaloperation; the ultra high vacuum levels are maintained throughout the beamline.

column4: NOAA/GML South Carolina Tower concrete pad
column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Global Monitoring Laboratory (GML) maintains atmospheric air trace gas measurement and sampling equipment on tall-towers for long-term atmospheric studies. The purpose of this request is to have concrete poured at new tower location at Barnwell, South Carolina (ASR 1059177), and to have our shipping container lifted onto the concrete pad once it has dried/cured. To pour a foundation/concrete pad to support a 20' shipping container (footprint 8' x 19'6"), pad size 10' x 21'6". The shipping container weight is ~5000lbs, and the contents will be on the order of 1000 lbs max. Vendor to determine need of rebar, thickness of concrete, base layer, etc. We will want to secure the shipping container to the platform, and want to imbed threaded rods into the concrete. After concrete has cured/dried, vendor will lift the 8 x 20 shipping container onto the concrete.

column5: The goal of this requirement is to enable traceable complex measurement for the microwave materials lab. The contractor shall deliver one (1) 20 GHz split cylinder cavity, one (1) 24 GHz split cylinder cavity, one (1) 50 GHz split cylinder cavity, one (1) 60 GHz split cylinder cavity, one (1) 1.85 mm female to 1.85 mm female electronic calibration units, two (2) 1.85 mm economy short, open, load mechanical calibration kits with uncertainties, two (2) 1.85 mm male to 1.85 mm male cables 1 meter in length, two (2) Precision Source/Measure Units, and two (2) 1.85 mm male to 1.85 mm male cables 24 inches in length. Delivery will be to NIST Boulder. Installation and training required. The electronics calibration unit and source measure unit items must include a 3-year extender warranty with maintenance.

column5: NOAA/ESRL/Global Monitoring Laboratory is in the process of procuring Picarro trace gas analyzers for near-simultaneous measurement of CO2, CH4, and H2O. Instruments to be procured must maintain or improve upon the precision of current aircraft and field instrumentation used within the NOAA Global Greenhouse Gas Reference Network ship-of-opportunity:Picarro G2301: a cavity ring-down spectrometer for measurements of carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor. This instrument is to be used to measure ambient air at surface and tall-tower sites.TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS: (Be specific)The G2301 analyzer must be capable of measuring:¿	CO2 in bulk air samples to or better than ± 0.05 parts per million (ppm) in 400 ppm¿	CH4 in bulk air samples to or better than ±0.5 nmol/mol (ppb) in 1800 ppbas 1-s over a 30-second averaging period.  The analyzer must have a measurement range of at least:¿	0  – 1000 ppm CO2¿	0 – 6 ppm CH4

column4: MULTI-MODE RADAR (MMR) REPAIR AND SERVICES IDIQ
column5: Indefinite Delivery-Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) type multiyear contract for repair of the Multi-Mode Radar (MMR) units and engineering services. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Aircraft Operations Center (AOC) has two MMR systems, one per WP-3D aircraft. The MMR is an integral part of hurricane surveillance and reconnaissance as delegated by various parts of NOAA, such as National Weather Service (NWS), Hurricane Research Division (HRD) and others. The MMR enables the pilots and in flight meteorologist to successfully navigate in and around tropical disturbances such as hurricanes, enabling the flight crew to maintain 360 degree situational awareness of the storm environment. The standard nose radar does not provide this capability.

column5: This 5 year PR is for research quality, calibrated measurements of atmospheric trace gases (e.g. CO2, CH4, CO, H2, N2O, SF6), and associated meteorological measurements (pressure, temperature, humidity), from several different altitudes up to approximately 25,000 ft, or as appropriate for the aircraft service ceiling. For the Global Greenhouse Gas Reference Network (GGGRN) atmospheric sampling site located approximately 10 miles offshore, southeast of Portsmouth, New Hampshire. These aircraft services are needed to measure trace gas species to improve our understanding of emissions location, source strength, and seasonality in support of air quality and climate science studies in support of the NOAA mission.

column5: The Polar Ecosystems Program (PEP) at NOAA’s Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC) requires aircraft services for population data collection of ice-associated seals and polar bears in the US-side of the Bering, Chukchi and Beaufort Seas from April through mid-June, 2025.  The aircraft will conduct aerial surveys of seals and polar bears on ice using a specially-designed belly-mounted camera system owned and operated by the PEP.  Surveys will be based out of various airfields along the Alaska coastline. Given a 200 lbs payload and two scientists, the aircraft must have a ground speed of X, and an endurance of Y for a survey range of Z.  The aircraft must have an open-air belly-port and the capability to mount and power an AFSC provided computer rack. The quote should include the time and cost to complete any fabrication and certifications needed to meet these requirements prior to the survey.
