column4: High Temperature Gel Permeation Chromatography (HT-GPC) Instrument
column5: This HT-GPC must include everything required to perform GPC at high temperatures: an integrated degasser, pump, dual-zone auto sampler, and oven.  System configuration will be dual detector system with a very sensitive, infrared concentration detector along with a differential viscometer.  The HT-GPC must be compatible with our existing multi-angle light scattering detector (Wyatt Technology Model Dawn Heleos II, 18 angle, with integrated heated transfer line). The HT-GPC system must be capable of absolute molecular mass determinations for polymers, particularly polyolefins and measure long-chain branching content, short chain branching content, along with dilute solution properties like intrinsic viscosity and radius of gyration as a function of molar mass.  Non-SRM samples may contain large concentrations of particulates, so sample preparation that removes insoluble additives from solutions, while preventing interaction of hot, toxic

column4: 2025 Telepresence-Enabled Ocean Exploration, Data Management and Remotely Operated Vehicle Systems
column5: Support the NOAA Ocean Exploration and Research (OER) at-sea exploration currently conducted on the NOAA Ship Okeanos Explorer. These same activities are expected to transition to the NOAA Ship Discoverer once commissioned.NOAA plans strategic priorities to evolve ship operations. Core areas will be identified by the contractor team in addition to addressing the following five (5) potential areas;1) management and maintenance support for an end-to-end telepresence system and related capabilities, 2) use of commercial off-the-shelf equipment, to enable scientists on shore to collaborate with ship-based personnel and participate in seagoing activities, primarily but not limited to, Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) operations from anywhere in the world with a standard internet connection; 3) use and advancement of a state-of-the-art remotely operated vehicle (ROV) system to achieve baseline characterization of unknown and poorly known s

column5: The NOAA Wage Mariner Program is seeking current comparative salary data for civilian professional mariners employed by the operators of U.S. flagships as identified by the Department of Transportation, Maritime Administration (MARAD). The data must include licensed and unlicensed wage rates (base and premium) for all Departments (Deck, Engine, Communication and Steward). To provide sufficient currency and completeness, the data at a minimum must include the current calendar year and the previous calendar year, and project to the next calendar year.

column4: NIST Radio Tower Inspection, Maintenance, Repair, and Modification
column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) owns sixteen (16) radio antenna towers in Ft. Collins, Colorado used by NIST radio stations WWVB and WWV. The towers form and/or support antennas that transmit standard time, standard frequencies, and NOAA space-weather information to the public. Regular inspection, maintenance, repairs, and modifications made relative to industry standards are required to keep the towers 1) operating continuously and safely under the range of expected weather conditions experienced in Ft. Collins, Colorado and 2) safe to climb when inspections, maintenance, repairs, or modifications are needed.

column5: NESDIS NOAA5006 uses Cisco equipment for its administrative networks at NESDIS Headquarters, NOAA JPSS Office (NJO), NOAA Satellite Operations Facility (NSOF), Office of Satellite Ground Services (OSGS), NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI-MD) Maryland, (NCEI-NC) Asheville Administrative LAN, (WCDAS) Wallops Command and Data Acquisition Station, (FCDAS) Fairbanks Command and Data Acquisition Station Administrative LAN, Comprehensive Large Array-data Stewardship System (CLASS) Administrative LAN across the NESDIS Enterprise. This equipment is currently covered by a Cisco SMARTnet Service maintenance contract, which needs to be renewed each year. NESDIS is requesting the renewal of Cisco SMARTnet service support maintenance contract under BPA for 12 consecutive months, with a base period of performance 9/10/2024 - 9/09/2025, with 3 Option Years.

column4: Air Resources Laboratory (ARL) Air Quality Research and Development Support Services - See PWS
column5: PROTECH Requirement - The Air Resources Laboratory (ARL) of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) conducts research and development in the fields of air quality, atmospheric dispersion, climate, and boundary layer science. Key activities include the development, evaluation, and application of air quality models; improvement of approaches for predicting atmospheric dispersion of hazardous materials; and the generation of new insights into air-surface exchange and climate variability and trends. Our Mission is to improve the ability of the Nation to protect human and ecosystem health and to support a vibrant economy through advanced atmospheric sciences and technologies.ARL requires scientists, engineers, and engineering technicians for specific Air Quality Research and Development support services to ARL.

column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL) operates a fleet of vessels ranging from 12’-85’ in length on the Great Lakes. Vessel Operations is managed from Muskegon, Michigan with vessels based at Muskegon, Alpena, Bay City, Manitowoc and Monroe. Qualified personnel are required to safely and efficiently operate and maintain these research vessels and NOAA shore and supporting facilities. Vessel personnel assignments, and cruise requirements are detailed by the GLERL Marine Superintendent based upon mission requirements, and vessel maintenance.

column4: NOAA VESSEL R8001 DRY DOCK WORK.
column5: Perform dry dock work on NOAA Vessel R8001 (Laurentian) within the Great Lakes Basin area. Work includes Haul and dry dock, hull services, prep and paint hull - keel to rail, inspect shaft bearing liners and stern tube bearings clearances, replace a shaft dry seal O-rings, service CPP propeller hub, remove and inspect main chest valve, black water holding tank renovation, fuel tank cleaning and inspection.

column5: NIST MEP has cooperative agreements with MEP Centers in every state and Puerto Rico, that make up the MEP National Network™ These cooperative agreements expect substantial involvement between the MEP Center and NIST MEP to act as public-private partners in the success of the MEP program. To assist in the financial strength of the MEP Centers, NIST MEP is developing an online training program for federal financial management and reporting by MEP Centers to ensure compliance with the MEP awards.

column4: Communications, Partnership, and Engagement (CPE) Support for 2026 Census Test

column4: Isotope analysis of multiple atmospheric trace gases and measurement of volatile organic compoundS
column5: Continuation of quantitative isotopic measurement from whole-air atmospheric samples identified in the attached Performance Work Statement.  The long term measurement performance must be demonstrated based on past performance in measuring repeat measurements from control cylinders.The laboratory (or laboratories) will be expected to have traceability to international reference materials that place sample data on established measurement scales.  Data should be available that will allow all samples to be post processed at any time to account for subsequent adjustments to reference scales.Lab shall provide processed initial results and subsequent QC revisions using NOAA IT approved remote access methodologies and CCGG group provided data processing routines to merge datasets into the primary data base repository.  Lab must be able to adjust the format and contents of result data files to meet changing requirements of the ingest sys

column4: Support of NIST Information Technology AI Resource Center & Database Applications
column5: The objective of this task order is computer science support in development of the NIST AI Resource Center which includes the development and testing of web-based information providing technologies; and support and enhancements for IAD AI evaluation projects launched last year. This will include taking part in existing research projects and developing software in support of research and evaluation activities.

column5: NCEI has a Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool in the CEREx/Salesforce application. This is a cloud-base tool which allows Customer Services Representatives (CSR) at NCEI to document customer interactions.  NCEI also has a legacy eCommerce system in the NCEI eCommerce System v2 running on premise.  This application was developed in-house over a decade ago.  This legacy application has a number of security issues, is dependent on the Oracle database technology stack, and is not integrated with the cloud-based CRM tool.  The objective of this project is to integrate the two systems resulting in a single CRM/eCommerce solution for the NCEI CSR using the CEREx/Salesforce application.

column4: Quantifying atmospheric methane point sources with NOAA satellite observations
column5: Our work will expand NOAA’s methane satellite remote sensing activities through four guiding objectives:•	Develop methane retrievals for NOAA’s LEO satellites (VIIRS).•	Develop methane retrievals for NOAA’s GEO satellites (GOES) and those of partner agencies (MTG, Himawari-8).•	Disseminate NOAA methane plume data through public data portals.•	Advance NOAA’s methane emissions work with partner agencies.

column5: Acquire a rotating telehandler with diesel engine and enclosed cab with heat and air conditioning.  Telehandler must have a minimum lifting height of 110 feet.  Telehandler must have the following attachments available:  1) remote controlled, telescopic working platform that accommodates two people 2) minimum 5,000-pound jib with 150 feet of cable.  Minimum 1-year, 2000-hour warranty whichever comes first.  The telehandler will come with operator’s manual, parts manual, and service manual.  Delivery and demonstration of the telehandler by authorized manufacturer’s representative.

column4: Satellite Ocean Color System Vicarious Calibration - Marine Optical BuoY (MOBY)
column5: MOBY system update and refresh - Assembly and full integration of the redesigned and upgraded MOBY optical systems and buoy framework, resulting in delivery of the final two (2) new (refreshed) and operation-ready MOBY systems.MOBY operations - The assurance of continuous functionality of a MOBY system in the marine environment deployed near Lanai, Hawaii and the provision of Department of Commerce (DOC) National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) traceable, quality controlled ocean color vicarious calibration data. Operations include:• Regular exchanges (recovery and deployment) of MOBY systems with proper commercial sea-going vessel coordination (on a quarterly basis).• Calibration of the MOBY system pre- and post-deployment with NIST traceable standards.• Refurbishment of recovered MOBY system prior to its next deployment;• Coordinating monthly SCUBA diver MOBY system cleanings (biofouling) and general infra

column4: Support for Research, Standardization, and development of Reference Materials for Multi-Party Threshold Cryptography, Privacy-Enhancing Cryptography and Interoperable Randomness Beacons
column5: Provide support to NIST through participation in the development of Privacy Enhancing Cryptography (PEC), including the areas of secure multiparty computation and zero knowledge proofs. The task will include support for the standardization of mutli-party threshold schemes (MPTC) and activities of interest to the Interoperable Randomness Beacons, related to the use of trusted randomness. The task includes research in scope with the Circuit Complexity project, including the compilation or development of circuits of interest. Support will be provided in the development and revision of NISTIRs and NIST SPs as well as recommendation reports related to  PEC, interoperable randomness beacons and multi-party threshold schemes

column4: Support for Lightweight Cryptography Standardization (Ascon), Block Cipher Modes and Password Hashing Schemes Development
column5: The objective of this task is to provide support to NIST in standardizing the selected lightweight cryptographic algorithm, Ascon, for resource-constrained devices. The task also includes developing a new mode of operation, called an accordion cipher mode, to address the limitations of the block cipher modes.  This task also provides support in the development of a memory-hard password hashing scheme that is effective in protecting against brute-force attacks.

column4: FY2025 Office of Advanced Manufacturing/Manufacturing USA Communications Support
column5: To support our public mission, the Office requires expertise and additional resources to complement internal staff capacity with: complex, national communications and educational outreach to target audiences that will improve brand awareness and engagement, disseminate information and engage the public on institute funding competitions and related funding opportunities and impacts from awards, strengthen thought leadership in advanced manufacturing, raise awareness of advanced manufacturing career pathways, and support the mission of Manufacturing USA and the institutes; expertise with writing and editing content (i.e., for the website and/or educational articles and reports) to explain the technology, work, and impact of the institutes in plain language to reach more manufacturers and potential institute members; assistance with digital and print materials such as: videography, photography, reports (including the Annual Report to Congr

column4: FY2025 Office of Advanced Manufacturing/Manufacturing USA Education and Workforce Development Support
column5: To support the Manufacturing USA network public mission and responsibilities under 15 U.S.C. § 278s to , the Office requires expertise and resources to complement internal staff resources and capabilities related to national education and workforce development efforts.  This includes providing support services to promote workforce development activities, identify and disseminate best practices for workforce education and training across the Network and further enhance collaboration among Manufacturing USA institutes in developing and implementing such practices, development of competency frameworks, and collaborations with the Department of Labor, the Department of Education, industry, career and technical education schools, local community colleges, universities, and labor organizations.

column5: Contractor shall provide technical expertise to update multiple publications to align them with the NIST CSF Version 2.0, draft OT cybersecurity articles for publication, and design laboratory test plans.The activities include, but are not limited to, updating the NIST “CSF Manufacturing Profile” (NIST IR 8183 Rev. 1) to align it with the NIST Cybersecurity Framework Version 2.0 (CSF 2.0), drafting articles on OT cybersecurity topics, investigating and reporting on required updates to the NIST “Guide to Operational Technology Security” (NIST SP 800-82 Rev. 3) to align it with CSF 2.0, collaborating on laboratory test plans, and collaborating on OT cybersecurity research.

column4: Evaluation and standardization of post-quantum cryptography (PQC)
column5: The objective of this task is to provide support to NIST in the evaluation and standardization of post-quantum cryptography (PQC). That includes mathematical and cryptanalytical research in code-based and multivariate-based key encapsulation mechanisms and digital signatures, support for the management of PQC research seminars, and support for the development of a standard based on the Falcon algorithm selected during the NIST PQC Standardization process. The task also includes supporting the revision of the statistical test suite documented in NIST SP 800-22 and the associated updates to the corresponding test tool.

column4: NWS Office of Observations Satellite Readiness Support
column5: This acquisition will ensure continued technical support services for NOAA/NWS's satellite readiness efforts.  This project supports the NWS Office of Observations Satellite Readiness project, providing contractor support-services in the areas of remote-sensing science, user and system requirements for satellite data, engineering, coordination and communication.  This project ensures the NWS has the support necessary for NWS to fully leverage current and emerging NOAA and non-NOAA satellite/observational data sources for service improvements across NWS mission areas.  (Contract vehicle: ProTech-Satellite)

column4: ESPC Project Facilitator Services (Matthew E. FY25)
column5: "ESPC Project Facilitator Services" will fund project engineering support for ESPC projects across the NMFS portfolio. NMFS is currently in the process of executing energy upgrade projects to meet energy performance requirements including Executive Order 14057 for net-zero energy performance. DOE best practices call for (DOE approved) project facilitators to review proposals including technical details and financing, as well as observe installation, commissioning, measurement and verification. The impact of the funding would help overall project success, helping NOAA to ensure that any task order award includes fair and reasonable pricing as well as technically viable and optimal energy conservation measures.

column4: Controlled Technology Assessment and Program Development (Fullem C. FY25)
column5: The objective is to obtain identifying controlled technology services. The contractor must possess an understanding of EAR, ITAR, Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC) regulations. The contractor will be tasked with assisting Fisheries in developing a baseline controlled technology inventory and providing recommendations on controls that could be used to prevent the unauthorized release of technology across all its locations to include any Fisheries owned research vessels. Additionally, the contractor will develop training to enable Fisheries Controlled Technology Points of Contact to maintain and update the baseline inventory, develop additional controls if needed, and how to determine if an export license is required and the process for obtaining the license if needed.

column5: NOAA CPO is seeking to procure a comprehensive Cloud Cost Management and Optimization (CCMO) tool. NOAA has migrated a significant portion of its resources to the cloud, but our cloud spending is outpacing our operational budget. We need a tool to effectively manage and optimize our cloud presence, provide visibility into spending, and automate cost-saving processes.This request is for a Base Year, 12 month Period of Performance (PoP) only.

column5: The project “RF Channel Propagation Measurements and Models for Communications Circuits” is based on the existing expertise and measurement methodology of the channel measurement and modeling team. This project aims to dramatically accelerate the time needed to develop models and measurements to industry stakeholders while also providing improved targeting of identified needs for maximum impact. The experimental portion of this work seeks to develop a new generation of channel sounder with FPGA and GPU integration for near real-time data processing.The experimental approach used by the NIST channel sounding team is to produce, transmit, receive, and subsequently digitize complex modulated radio-frequency waveforms to provide improved dynamic range as needed to measure lossy communications channels. column5: The SMS vehicle is a blanket purchase agreement (BPA) with the goal to have the government be aware of and prepared to implement decisions made at an organizational level. This SMS requirement is integral to the success of the program providing the Decision Support, Enterprise Architecture Services, and Project Management Services necessary for the short- and long-term planning required to support the implementation of the OCIO strategic goals.  SMS refers to the system – processes, programs, tools, and behavioral norms – as NOAA seeks to further develop its IT strategy, translate its IT operational actions, and ensure its IT management has continuous improvement and innovation.

column5: SAE requires a service for usability testing of web properties. The tool must have an easy set-up process and a user-friendly graphical user interface (GUI) to conduct user testing on websites or other digital products. Key features must include the ability to set up a usability test with a remote subject; the ability to record (both voice and screen) the test session; the ability to use our own test subjects and also to employ test subjects provided through the service

column4: Award 5-year BPA for New Paving and Road Repairs at the NESDIS FCDAS Campus in Fairbanks, Alaska
column5: NESDIS intends to award a multi-year BPA contract to perform the new paving and existing road repairs required at the NESDIS FCDAS campus in Fairbanks, Alaska.  The FCDAS facility only has a brief summer window of good weather to perform this outside work, so the overall paving project is expected to require up to 5-years to complete.

column5: This contract shall be a vehicle for the U.S. Census Bureau (USCB) to create, test and operate a multi-channel contact center in support of the 2030 Census Questionnaire Assistance (2030 CQA) program.This solicitation will include all efforts and technology required to design, test, fine-tune, install, operate and decommission the contact center systems, facilities, processes and human resources in support of the 2030 Census.  The contractor shall provide all management, supervision, equipment and labor, and shall plan, schedule, coordinate, and ensure effective performance of all 2030 CQA requirements.

column5: The NESDIS Commercial Data Program (CDP) pursues demonstration projects on behalf of NOAA and assesses the viability of assimilating commercially provided satellite data and products to diversify NOAA’s portfolio of data collection capabilities. For this Pilot Study, NOAA will assess the quality and impact of available commercial microwave sounder observations for the determination of MWS characteristics.  NOAA will use Pilot Study data to investigate the utility of MWS products developed by commercial vendors while also addressing the potential benefits of adding multiple MW sounding orbits (vis-a-vis commercial MWS supplemental missions) over the current Government backbone to show improved benefits to NWP as a saturation of these MW observations has not been observed.

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Office of Financial Management (OFRM) needs to procure IT services to support its business applications.  The National Institute of Standards & Technology (NIST) uses many business applications to support financial, acquisition, grants, Other Transaction Authorities (OTAs) , loans, and travel business operations. Functional and technical support for these applications is provided by business systems support personnel within the NIST Office of Information Systems Management (OISM) and the Office of Financial Resources Management (OFRM). This business systems support function is hereafter referred to as NIST Business Systems Support (BSS). The purpose of this requirement is for a Contractor to provide functional and technical support services required for the NIST BSS including but not limited to: program management, project management, tier 2 Customer Support, training & user docu

column5: This contract intends to support evaluation, research, and planning for the Manufacturing Extension Partnership (MEP) Program at NIST. The objective for this contract is to assist the NIST MEP National Network in areas of economic research, evaluation, network performance, leveraging multiple sources of data and other areas designed to improve the performance and impacts of the MEP National Network. NIST MEP has developed and leveraged an integrated approach for developing program strategy, measuring program performance, and monitoring program outcomes and impacts. While this approach has served as a model for other government programs, it has often leveraged independent and trusted third-party expertise to validate its impacts and explore research topics of interest to the National Network and other MEP stakeholders.

column5: The National Weather Service (NWS) will be moving the Honolulu Weather Forecast Office (WFO) to the Daniel K. Inouye Regional Center (IRC) on Ford Island.  The move is being conducted to save money for the NWS since the IRC is a NOAA building that currently has open space.  The NWS will not have to use the General Service Administration (GSA) as a third party lease designator saving the NWS significant savings in upgrades to the current WFO and well as GSA fees.  This Requirement will be to hire an Architectural and Engineering (A&E) firm to design/build/remodel the IRC in order to convert the empty space into a location that the WFO Operations area can utilize.

column5: This requirement will provide both engineering and program support to the SLEP program, in ways such as design and production review and assessment, engineering support for deployment of systems to all geographic locations, management of the Integrated Master Schedule of the entire project, budget tracking and management support, and other tasks as needed by the program and project managers.  Because much of the engineering support required through production and deployment of the new system is non-recurring engineering, and because the schedule is complex in integrates several interrelated tasks in diverse areas, and also because the budget is incorporated into Construction Work in Progress (CWIP) tracking, continued support of contractor labor will be needed through the completion of the ASOS SLEP project.

column4: ROV Long Range Lobster Gear Inspection Operations
column5: The Government intends to procure services of a 46-60' Downeast lobster style vessel that by design is intended to efficiently and safely haul and reset commercial lobster gear in New England waters not to exceed 80 nautical miles (NM) from shore.  Law Enforcement personnel will provide an Agency owned and operated ROV and Side Scan Sonar to collect imagery of lobster gear. LE personnel will request the hauling of suspected non-compliant gear aboard the vessel for inspection to ensure compliance with federal fisheries and protected resource regulations.

column5: The primary objective of the project is to apply a protective coating to the offshore structure, which will prevent corrosion and ensure the integrity of the structure is maintained. The recoating project will include surface preparation, blasting, and painting, utilizing high-quality coatings and techniques that meet the applicable standards and regulations. The coating will be applied to the entire structure, including the underwater portion, to ensure complete protection against corrosion.

column4: UCAR engineering consultation, scientific support, and implementation assistance.
column5: The Radar Operations Center (ROC) Engineering Branch, requires engineering consultation, scientific support, and implementation assistance for the development of radar signal processing software and analysis for improving the quality of the base data from the WSR-88D Polarimetric Doppler weather radar.  This purchase request is being submitted to continue to obtain these services from the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research/National Center for Atmospheric Research (UCAR/NCAR) Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) contract. This organization has been designated as a Federally Funded Research and Development Center (FFRDC) for its role as a unique National resource for atmospheric research and related sciences.

column4: Standards Development for Atom Probe Tomography, LEAP
column5: The Material Measurement Laboratory (MML) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) is involved in materials characterization efforts to support multiple projects.  Materials characterization allows NIST scientists to make direct correlations between material processing, (nano)structure, and resulting properties.  This work involves three-dimensional (3D) atomic imaging of nanoscale samples in an atom probe tomography (APT) instrument.  An APT instrument: (1) accepts nanoscale needle-shaped specimens and specimen array coupons for analysis, (2) triggers field ion evaporation of the specimen, (3) detects the emitted ions in time and space, and (4) generates a 3-Dimensional (3D) computational reconstruction of the evaporated volume that can be used in further analysis. In this work, the APT instrument should trigger field ion evaporation with either a voltage pulse, a deep-ultraviolet (¿ < 280 nm) laser pulse, or a sync

column4: Strategic Communications, Program/Project Mgmt, and Subject Matter Expertise Support [ProTech Weath]
column5: OCAO is requesting the establishment of a Firm Fixed Price and Time and Materials Task Order under the ProTech - Weather Strategic Sourcing Initiative. The purpose of this task is to provide program and project management support to assist OCAO. This scope includes (a) portfolio, program, project management support (b) administrative, logistics, analysis, communication, and policy review support to facilitate planning, (c) advanced Smartsheet expertise to develop and maintain OCAO program/project solutions using advanced features including Control Center and Data Shuttle, and (d) the expertise of a communications specialists to provide strategic communication services that will organize and coalesce the messaging for the strategic initiatives across a broad audience consisting of NOAA employees and Leadership to Whitehouse and Congressional staff.

column4: OCAO Facilities Project Management Support - Replacement
column5: The NOAA HQ Facility Modernization Initiative will promote effective space management practices, program collocation, and consolidation opportunities to enhance program collaboration and synergies and improve operational efficiencies. The Contractor shall provide OCAO-FPO project management support from the conceptual phase through to close out practices, following project management principles, practices and procedures.

column5: Contractor shall provide labor support in support of National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC), Operations, Management, and Information Division (OMI) serves as the focal point for the NEFSC's budget and finance functions, labor relations, strategic planning, grants and acquisition, environmental compliance and safety, personal property.  OMI is responsible for the Center and Region public affairs, constituent affairs, media relations, technical editing and publishing, research libraries, and library services.  Oversight of the Woods Hole Science Aquarium, a research and public display aquarium, also lies within this Division.  The Research Vessel Gloria Michelle is also managed under this Division.

column4: RFIMS Program Operations and Maintenance Support (OM&S)
column5: The purpose of this contract is to ensure operations, maintenance, and sustainment of the current operational Radio Frequency Interference Monitoring System (RFIMS). The RFIMS was previously developed and the initial systems were deployed under the RFIMS development contract.The contractor shall provide the operation, maintenance, and sustainment support as described in the following subsections. This applies to all hardware, software and firmware utilized in the operation, and maintenance of RFIMS.

column4: Super High Resolution Darkfield Scattering-Confocal Raman Microscope
column5: Currently, the main approaches for single particle (sub-20nm) counting are ICP-MS, and laser scattering. Industry is unable to measure/control baseline impurities below 1 PPT (parts per trillion, based on dissolved ions). The BIG concern is distinguishing the instrument noise from the actual particle signal. To address this measurement challenge, we also aim at understanding the factors that govern the surface deposition of such nanoparticles to develop methods for their controlled and predictable deposition. These factors include chemical interactions and physical shape of the nanofeatures on the surface of interest. In part of this effort, we will use fluorescence, Raman and dark-field optical microscopies that are powerful tools for detecting nanoparticles down to few nanometers in size. These optical methods tandem with other high-resolution and high-sensitivity surface analytical instrumentations will be used to develop novel metho

column5: The Government intends to procure  a multi-year IDIQ solicitation to replace the aging IFR1200S Service Monitor.  The IFR1200S is an analog Radio Frequency Communications Monitor which is the current measurement standard used by NWS Electronics Technicians in the course of their duties performing routine and corrective maintenance. The IFR1200S equipment is beyond obsolescence and experiencing high failure rates during annual calibration. The second-hand market of replacement parts and components is shrinking.

column4: IT Support Services for the NMFS Alaska Region
column5: Requirement is for Information Technology (IT) support services for the NMFS Alaska Regional Office. These IT support services must enable several operational objectives, including: office operations of regional staff; program specific operations such as permitting, quota management, and fisheries monitoring; communication with stakeholders including government agencies, commercial fishing industry actors, and the general public. One base year and four option years.

column4: Southeast Right Whale Early Warning System
column5: The main objectives of the requirement are:1. Use aerial survey methods to monitor calf production in North Atlantic right whales.2. Use aerial survey methods to collect North Atlantic right whale location data in nearshorecontinental shelf waters of the Southeast U.S. coast.3. Use established photographic identification techniques to collect photographs for use inphoto-identification of individual whales.4. Communicate sighting locations to federal and other marine users consistent with EarlyWarning System (EWS) survey protocols.This data collection and notification effort will compliment other right whale-related datacollection activities planned along the U.S. East Coast.

column5: The Government intends to procure ARGOS satellite telemetry services for NOAA Fisheries. The requirement is necessary for a satellite data transmission service that is compatible with platform transmitter terminals (PTT) and is capable of providing data transmitted by PTTs in near-real time, in a standardized format. Woods Hole Group is the US-based subsidiary of CLS Group and is the sole provider of the Argos satellite communication services for receiving transmissions from PTTs and providing those data in a standardized format.The NOAA/NMFS will utilize this service for several critical missions to manage and protect sea turtle populations. One goal is to support the Deepwater Horizon Sea Turtle Early Restoration Project emergency response preparedness efforts during sea turtle cold stunning events in Texas. The team will install floating, satellite transmitting, water temperature devices to provide real-time inshore water tempera

column4: Sea Turtle Emergency Response Tent Rental
column5: The National Marine Fisheries Service, Office of Protected Resources (NMFS-OPR) operates the Deepwater Horizon (DWH) Sea Turtle Early Restoration Project which focuses heavily on stranding and mortality investigations, as well as support for emergency response within the Gulf of Mexico. Response to catastrophic sea turtle stranding events, such as cold-stunning and oil spills, are critical in population management and recovery. An important component in emergency response work is having resources readily available to provide near real time support for the large number of sea turtles being impacted in their natural environment. These events can occur at any time and in any location by the coast of the Gulf of Mexico. The ability to provide a large pop-up structure out of the elements to house a triage and recovery area could increase survival of sea turtles by hundreds, and possibly thousands of individuals. This has a real impact on p

column4: Real-time Continuous Inductive Hypoxia Monitoring System
column5: To continue the establishment of a Bay-wide hypoxia monitoring program to attain water column dissolved oxygen data for the purposes of water quality monitoring and fish habitat assessments. This monitoring program will assist the Chesapeake Bay Bay Program’s effort to move its water quality monitoring program from “fair to good.” Establishment of this program will be accomplished via a Project Coordinator and support staff to support operations and maintenance. It will also require the acquisition of equipment and associated supplies.

column4: Recompete for Atlantic Surfclam-Ocean Quahog Vessel Charter
column5: Recompete base +4 for Atlantic Surfclam-Ocean Quahog Survey - The Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC) Surfclam and Ocean Quahog Survey is conducted using a hydrodynamic dredge in the Western Atlantic continental shelf region off the Eastern United States, from North Carolina to Georges Bank. The region-wide survey targets Atlantic surfclam, Spisula solidissima, and ocean quahog, Arctica islandica and provides indices of abundance and recruitment for both species. Award needed by July/August 2025.

column4: Funnel and Injection Mold for NWS Standard Rain Gauge.
column5: The National Weather Service (NWS) measures precipitation with an 8-Inch rain gauge, known as the "Standard Rain Gauge." This gauge is operated and maintained at over 5,000 locations.  This rain gauge requires a "Funnel" (also known  as a 'Collector') and it is a high usage part for the NWS Cooperative Observer Program (COOP).  The agency stock number for the Funnel is, D040-MP1.  The procurement of 300 units in FY25 is needed to replenish logistics supply stock for the COOP Program.  The NWS has 257 on back-order as of FEB 20, 2025.  A document containing price quotes from several vendors is attached to this requisition.  The purpose of this acquisition is to procure 300 Funnels and a plastic-injection mold from a vendor who complies with the NWS specifications for the Funnel for the Standard Rain Gauge.  The plastic-injection mold is required because NWS is without one and the past vendor that owns one is charging unacceptably high un

column4: Astronics CSC - Sabre AIO Unit Instrument Purchase
column5: NOAA requires an Avionics IO (AIO) computer and associated cables that will provide an interface with the commercial aircraft and the instrument. The AIO will allow NOAA to read avionics data in order to know where in space and time the greenhouse gas measurements were taken, as well as wind, temperature, and pressure data.  The AIO will also allow NOAA to upload data to a server using aircraft indicators such as weight on wheels and passenger door open so that NOAA staff can perform quality control of the data during the year-long NGAS deployment. As such, this requirement requires NOAA to design software to run these functions as intended when installed on the aircraft. Here, we aim to develop software in the laboratory that so that the AIO (1) can read avionics data signals and (2) operate a cellular modem for data upload so that when installed in a commercial aircraft, the NGAS will function as expected. The AIO and associated c

column4: General Implementation Support for AI Risk Management Guidance
column5: This project's purpose is to support the promotion, operationalization and adoption of the NIST AI RMF and related profiles across private industry and other settings, support the work of the US AI Safety Institute Consortium, and the development of guidance for safe and trustworthy generative AI technologies.  The Contractor shall provide advice and guidance on technology policy matters related to trustworthy and responsible AI in support of the adoption of the AI RMF, and other NIST AI efforts like the US AI Safety Institute Consortium.

column5: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory (GLERL) operates a fleet of vessels ranging from 12'-85' in length on the Great Lakes. Vessel Operations is managed from Muskegon, Michigan with vessels based at Muskegon, Alpena, and Bay City, Michigan as well as Manitowoc, WI and Monroe, OH. Qualified personnel are required to safely and efficiently operate and maintain these research vessels and NOAA shore and supporting facilities. Vessel personnel assignments, and cruise requirements are detailed by the GLERL Marine Superintendent based upon mission requirement and vessel maintenance

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Materials Measurement Laboratory, Materials Science and Engineering Division (https://www.nist.gov/mml/materials-science-and-engineering-division), seeks to acquire a confocal Raman microscope spectrometer for advanced interface analysis in computer chip manufacturing. This instrument will enable crucial insights into the electrochemical processes involved in creating microelectronics interconnects, from on-chip metallizations to through-silicon vias for chip stacking and advanced packaging. To better understand how these interconnects are fabricated, particularly in filling complex 3D structures, we need to map local surface chemistry across patterned wafers.Specifically, the acquisition of a confocal Raman microscope with enhanced spectroscopic capabilities will support research on surfactant-mediated film growth, critical for superconformal filling processes. column5: The purpose of this project is to provide the necessary measurement infrastructure to enable high confidence in manufacturing reliable devices containing advanced materials (herein 2D and wide-band gap materials). Reliability and provenance are often not considered early in electronics development, but they are essential steps of advanced electronic systems necessary for national security and defense applications.  This project addresses a significant pitfall in electronics for national security that are based on wide-band gap materials and builds out measurement framework for early adoption of next-generation electronics containing 2D materials as functional components.

column5: We will create measurement technology, reference data and materials to perform trace impurity gas analysis at new levels of precision. Success will enable next-generation diagnostics to reliably identify impurities in process gases at sub-parts-per-billion (<1 ppb) levels. Results will drive partners to develop industry-ready reference materials, point-of-use diagnostics and models to achieve breakthroughs in critical tooling like extreme ultra-violet lithography. Our diagnostics and metrology-grade data will enhance quality systems by establishing a framework for impurity fingerprinting with traceability to new gas primary standards, reference materials and documentary standards.

Success will enable next-generation diagnostics to reliably identify impurities in process gases at sub-parts-per-billion (<1 ppb) levels. Results will drive partners to develop industry-ready reference materials, point-of-use diagnostics and models to achieve breakthroughs in critical tooling like extreme ultra-violet lithography. Our diagnostics and metrology-grade data will enhance quality systems by establishing a framework for impurity fingerprinting with traceability to new gas primary standards, reference materials and documentary standards.

column4: High Resolution chromatography and mass spectrometry
column5: Semiconductor manufacturing yield enhancement requires ongoing risk analysis of cleaning chemical purity wherein critical contaminants are already at levels difficult or impossible to detect, let alone identify and quantify. Next generation chips will require even purer materials and advanced metrological capabilities for the detection, identification, and quantification of impurities in semiconductor cleaning chemicals necessitating a practical roadmap for assessing material purity commensurate with the needs of the next generation in semiconductor manufacturing. To this end, three projects addressing different components of this theme are proposed: organic contaminant identification and quantification, native particulates and precursors and rapid surface particle-, and impurity detection and quantification in water/non-water solvents.

column5: We will develop new Standard Reference Materials (SRMs), Reference Materials (RMs), and Research Grade Test Materials (RGTMs) of high-purity solids currently lacking in chips manufacturing, enabling more effective, efficient, and comparable characterizations of source materials, as well as process control improvements. To achieve these goals, we will develop new NIST capabilities in glow discharge mass spectrometry (GDMS) and laser-based analytical methods, and we will significantly lower detection limits for existing NIST nuclear techniques. Technology transfer will enable U.S. industry to establish new measurement capabilities in their own facilities, and NIST will provide access to the newly established NIST measurement facilities via suitable collaborative agreements

column5: Precise measurements of thermal properties at the nanoscale are needed for engineering of advanced and heterogeneously integrated devices but are currently unattainable. We will radically advance thermal metrology by developing new tools for mapping thermal conductivity (¿) and interfacial thermal conductance (G) at the nanoscale, with high precision (¿¿<5%, ¿G<10%) and throughput (˜25·106improvement). This will be achieved by wide bandwidth detection of the transient photothermal expansion of a sample using either NIST-made optomechanical AFM probes (˜10¿nm resolution, 20 ms/pixel) or a far-field, super-resolution microscope (˜500 nm resolution, ˜5 µs/pixel, ˜100 µm depth sensitivity).

column5: The semiconductor industry continues to push for smaller features, more integration, and increased yield. New photoresist chemistries and advances in extreme ultraviolet lithography are enabling this trend. However, this is inhibited by a lack of measurements describing heterogeneities in chemistry that contribute to the quality of photoresist patterns at these smaller dimensions. This includes fundamental questions into how the EUV exposure changes the resist chemistry and its spatial extent, and the underlying mechanisms that produce those changes. Our proposed NIST team will characterize the properties of advanced lithographic materials, measure nanoscale chemical distributions, and study the patterning process in situ. This will be accomplished by further developing a suite of metrology techniques which have tailored sensitivity to both the chemistry and structure of the photoresists and how the exposure processes influence critical

column5: The semiconductor industry requires sub-nm, 3-dimensional quantitative elemental mapping of materials, nanoscale structures, and devices with high analytical sensitivity for process development, failure analysis, and competitive engineering. Atom probe tomography (APT) is recognized by industry as the method that can address these goals. However, commercially available atom probe tomography instruments and methodologies are inadequate. This project will make critical metrology advancements in APT instrumentation, experimental methods, data analysis, and modeling and simulation. With these new tools, industry will increase yield, improve device performance, and accelerate time to market.

column5: We will use scatterometry to benefit advanced integrated circuits (IC) manufacturing.  We propose to develop novel extreme ultraviolet (EUV) optics, tabletop sources, and methodologies for inspection and process control. This project will innovate novel approaches to utilizing the 10 nm to 150 nm spectral range for chemical and dimensional characterization of leading-edge technologies over the next decade. NIST is uniquely positioned as our SURF III synchrotron is an optimal source for this radiation, allowing parallel work on metrological aspects with an in-lab compact source. Through a combination of ten times greater spatial resolution in each dimension and the ability to penetrate materials using shorter wavelengths, we will achieve an increase in the information gathered through fast optical techniques by a factor of 1000. We will proactively transfer these technologies to U.S. industry through existing and expanded relationships.

column5: Mechanical strain impacts the performance of semiconductor devices. Manufacturing processes must be carefully controlled for strain to achieve high yielding and high-performance products.  However, measuring strain in nanoscale devices remains a metrology challenge for manufacturers. Different techniques (EBSD, TKD, 4-D STEM, Raman, µXRD, etc.) are either commercially available or under development to address this need, with NIST making significant contributions to these methods. As geometric complexity and importance of strain continues to increase, we intend to continue advancing these techniques, improving their accuracy, and supply new reference materials to ensure capabilities for future-generation devices.

column4: Boulder EUV Source Use (Budget Mod Eval)
column5: Extreme ultraviolet (EUV) light is critical technology for modern semiconductor manufacturing, but there are no standards for EUV light characterization, in particular power and energy, at industrial conditions. EUV lithography is required for fabrication of advanced semiconductor chips and requires the generation of 100s of Watts of EUV light. EUV lithography requires support tools, such as reflectivity and transmission measurements, that also require generation of EUV light, but at lower powers and energies. The work in this proposal will empower NIST to work with industry to create relevant power and energy measurement capabilities for the present and future.

column5: Foundry-based fabrication and metrology tools are critical to accelerate mainstream adoption of CMOS biochemical sensors. A key technical bottleneck preventing such widespread use of CMOS biosensors centers around the rigorous functional requirements governing the interface of electronics with biology. We propose to overcome these barriers by developing a set of unique operando chemical and electrical measurements along with companion predictive models to provide high-resolution characterization of the functional building blocks of biointerfaces that will enable the development of robust, manufacturable interface materials and processes. Importantly the tools, processes and models developed here will transform biointerface deposition and characterization from academic research to a manufacturable tool suitable for commercial deployment. The main outputs of this effort will be new operando tools, high quality data sets, optimized process

column5: Some of the manufacturing difficulties encountered by the heterogeneous integration of modular chips in system-in-package are due to thermal management and mechanical incompatibilities among the various interfaces and building blocks of the package. This project will provide indentation and scanning probe-based measurements for the process-induced alterations of the thermo-mechanical properties of materials and structures used in advanced packages. Building on our decades-long expertise in nanoscale to microscale mechanical property measurements on microelectronic materials, we will improve and deliver measurement methodologies and data to industry to enhance their predictive manufacturing.

column5: Semiconductor manufacturers use internationally agreed upon, known-value material artifacts to weigh improvements in market share against the cost of switching to materials that may improve performance. Today, no such standard exists for complex permittivity, which is a key property necessary for the design of any semiconductor electronic device. As a result, a raw material producer (suppliers such as Murata) and a material consumer (foundry such as Intel) may disagree on the measured value of the complex permittivity of a given sample and currently have no mutually agreed upon method to know the correct value. This CHIPS proposal develops a traceability path for complex permittivity and develops new standard reference materials for complex permittivity up to 80 GHz (for 5G and computing applications) and potentially up to 325 GHz (for 6G and photonics applications).

column5: We will develop new metrology to measure size-appropriate and microstructure-appropriate mechanical properties up to fracture of copper (Cu) films for Cu hybrid bonding, and as stretch goal we will also measure similar properties of SAC solders. These micromechanical properties are currently lacking or sparse but are critical as inputs for improving the accuracy of finite element models and multi-scale physics models of the Cu bonding process and solder reliability. We will develop micro-specimen design and fabrication methods, testing methods using state-of-the-art commercial tools initially, and then develop new measurement instruments based on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) actuators. The MEMS-based instruments will potentially enable higher accuracy, resolution, and throughput than the commercial tools. Properties of samples we make ourselves will be publicly available through an open data repository, while the properties of

column5: Current reliability practices are not equipped to address new failure mechanisms induced by the increased localized heat production and mismatch of coefficients of thermal expansion in advanced packaging, especially for applications requiring long-term high reliability under harsh service environments. 1 This project will develop multi-stress accelerated testing, in-situ property monitoring, failure analysis, and predictive modeling for reliability of advanced packaging. Open-source dataset on physical properties of critical materials (thermal interface materials, redistribution layers, underfills, etc.) and their relevant interfaces under environmental stresses will be provided, with recommendations for improving standards for testing long-term reliability of advanced packaging.

column5: The length scale over which light is used for communication in information processing systems has steadily reduced. Silicon photonics is now crucial down to the chip scale, with major semiconductor companies such as Intel, Nvidia, and HP incorporating photonic transceiver chips with processors at the package level. To maximize the impact of silicon photonics for the semiconductor ecosystem, several measurement needs must be urgently addressed. Within this CHIPS effort, our team will focus on two thrusts that have been identified as key priorities by the integrated photonics industry: the development of specific test structure designs and a general design methodology that enable optimized measurements for extraction of device and material optical properties, and the measurement and mitigation of optical loss caused by induced surface roughness in photonic structures.

column5: Advanced semiconductor technology has led to continuous performance improvements in transistors. However, many iterations are needed to obtain optimal performance and the yield and reproducibility is incredibly poor. Furthermore, US chip makers are ill-equipped with legacy measurement techniques and underperforming models. We propose a robust path to develop and verify high-frequency transistor models:  1) new on-wafer standards and calibration, 2) precision noise measurements for transistor quality assurance, 3) improved characterizations, 4) optimal models tailored to a given technology, and 5) transistor model verification across frequency with key performance indicators.

column4: Process development for APSM sets of overlay wafers
column5: IC production relies on measurements of the 3D size, shape, and placement of structures with atomic-level precision and repeatability. As the IRDS identified, SEM overlay measurements are already problematic due to complex 3D structures, material variety, and low signal intensities.  This project will create a sound scientific foundation and comprehensive solutions for overlay and any SEM dimensional metrology superior to currently used arbitrary methods. This will allow the design of overlay patterns, acquisition, and image analysis to be optimized entirely through artificial intelligence, physics-based simulation, and modeling and meet IRDS requirements now and in the future.

column5: Superconformal Cu electrodeposition is a central process in manufacturing microelectronic interconnects. This project will employ operando electrochemical surface science measurements, feature filling experiments, and modeling to examine the mechanisms, optimization, and extendibility of trench and via superfilling for nanometer scale interconnects. Further, because Cu performance is substantially degraded at such dimensions, these capabilities will also be applied to processes for fabricating alternative interconnect materials, Co, Rh, Ir, and intermetallics thereof, identified by industrial and academic partners as they promise electrical performance superior to Cu at the nanoscale.

column5: Wide bandgap power devices are key to an all-electric future. Most of the applications in this all-electric future (automotive, aerospace, etc.) have extreme reliability requirements, such as less than 1 ppm failure in 25 years. Ensuring such extreme reliability requires careful modeling and use of aggressive guard-banding (de-rating parts) and redundancy to overcome risks due to incomplete or low-confidence reliability data. Fundamentally, there is a remarkable time cost associated with performing statistically significant long-term reliability tests with appropriate lifetime acceleration physics. This time cost is so steep that industry has turned to more expedient tests to test larger numbers of devices. The direct correlation between these rapid tests and long-term reliability is generally missing. As a result, designers of high reliability systems are left with an incomplete picture which further perpetuates the perceived need for

column5: Plasma etching—performed across the semiconductor manufacturing ecosystem—is a highly nonlinear process involving arbitrary radiofrequency (RF) waveforms, dynamic electrical properties, and complex chemistry in a confined non-equilibrium environment. Metrology tools are needed to better correlate reactor inputs with etching outcomes, and to precisely evaluate consistency across plasma etching tools. To do so, we will develop RF waveform metrology and µs time-resolved frequency comb diagnostics to meet industry needs including reliable RF calibration, in-situ monitoring of plasma chemistry, and real-time data generation for intelligent design of next-generation plasma etching processes.

column5: Advanced models for semiconductor fabrication unit processes are needed for improved process control, defect reduction, and ultimately yield improvement. Traditional physics-based models suffer from long computational times and a lack of relevant process data needed for validation, limiting their utility in the fab. We propose to augment physics-based multi-scale models with artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) to create a digital twin (DT) of a critical semiconductor fabrication process – Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD). To do this, we will produce physical process data in an optically-accessible ALD reactor and train physics-informed AI/ML models against the data. Process data generated for model training will enable industry and academia to build and validate their own models. This proposal will also support other CHIPS R&D efforts, including those in GC4 and GC6.

column5: Advanced in situ and operando methods for real time monitoring of the chemical status of wafer surfaces, thin films, and interfaces during plasma processing are essential for semiconductor process development and control. We will build upon NIST's leading expertise in plasma-surface interaction, plasma diagnostics, and operando photoelectron spectromicroscopy to develop a new plasma-XPS metrology platform for quantitative sub-monolayer sensitive in-situ chemical analysis of wafer surfaces during plasma processing. This innovative metrology will be a valuable addition to the next node semiconductor process development and inspection toolset and, in a broader scope, to the fundamental measurement science of plasma-surface interaction. We will collaborate with industrial partners (see letters of support) and academia in the development, implementation, and dissemination of plasma-XPS metrology. column5: Atom Probe Tomography (APT) is a powerful tool for the semiconductor industry, offering the unique ability to identify and map the chemical identity and location of individual atoms with spatial resolution at or below the smallest critical dimensions found in modern devices. These capabilities have led most major semiconductor manufacturers to install APT systems at their manufacturing facilities and/or R&D labs.  Significant advances in the technique have been made in recent years, however, industry adoption as a true metrology tool is still held back by measurement inaccuracies that may be overcome by using standards. This project will produce a series of industrially relevant reference materials, data sets, and standard practices that will improve the accuracy and repeatability of quantitative measurements made by APT. These standards will also serve as critical benchmarking standards going forward, allowing semiconductor manufacture

column5: Design, implement, and enhance data capture procedures (with Guided Data Capture (GDC) software developed at NIST) for the thermophysical and thermochemical properties of metal-based systems, with a concentration on pure metals and binary and ternary mixtures of metals, but also to include systems of an arbitrary number of components. This data will be derived primarily from original sources published in the scientific literature and an assessment of uncertainty will be done at the time of capture.  The data captured must be added to the existing NIST Alloys database infrastructure.  Finally, the process of making this data available through the NIST Alloys Data web interface (https://trc.nist.gov/metals_data) must be completed.

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) requires a programmable microwave signal generator for performing electron spin resonance (ESR) experiments with an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) scanning probe system (SPM). Measuring and manipulating the quantum state properties of electron spin systems is a critical part of the NIST mission in quantum information science.  To fulfill this requirement, NIST requires a programmable microwave signal generator that will provide the necessary approximately 1-40 GHz microwave magnetic field to induce ESR transitions The microwave signal generator must be compatible with and exactly replaceable with an existing Keysight E8267D microwave generator.

column4: Trusted Enterprise Infrastructure (TEI) Routers, Firewall, and Network Switches
column5: The National Cybersecurity Center of Excellence (NCCoE) TEI applied research project goal is to build a typical enterprise environment to demonstrate real-world challenges in modernizing the architecture to support multicloud, software-defined network (SDN), internet protocol version 6 (IPv6), software-defined wide area network (SDWAN), etc. while adopting current cybersecurity practices like zero trust principles by utilizing advanced technologies to control access driven by policy, mitigate cyber threats, and provide visibility within the environment. To accomplish this goal, advanced routing elements including the Cisco 8000 series router with advanced Internetwork Operating Systems (IOS) are needed, specifically at the edge to support required protocols such as multiprotocol label switching (MPLS) Customer Edge, SDN, SDWAN and additional security features.

column4: Cluster Primary and Compute Cluster Backup
column5: Support for the SDN capabilities provided by TEI, additional server hardware is needed. The current computer cluster systems used for TEI consist of old equipment that cannot be upgraded to improve both processing and networking speeds. Additionally, the old hardware has reached an end of life and should be replaced with a modern system capable of high-speed low-latency processing systems.

column4: Process Control System Testbed with Support for Industry 4.0 digitalization
column5: Utilizing a testbed conveyor belt system and robotic control system has been built in the NIST NCCoE Manufacturing Lab. This testbed currently provides a good research and training platform for studying the cybersecurity challenges facing the general discrete control system for manufacturing industry. However, the need for securing manufacturing systems is not confined to the discrete control system.  To address the needs of manufacturers who operate process control systems, the NCCoE Manufacturing Lab is proposing a new physical process control system testbed to be built in NCCoE to study the attack surfaces associated specifically with process control systems.

column5: The Government intends to procure dolphin salinity tags for NOAA Fisheries. The research and development of these tags is essential to measure the salinity of the water where the dolphins are located. The requirement will be to design, create, and test these tags in phases. The tags will need to be compatible to transmit data to a satellite once in the final stage and complete. NOAA/NMFS will use these tags for several critical missions to record measurements across varying salinity levels from 0 to 30 in diverse environments, including different depths and water qualities.

column5: The NOAA Office of Low Earth Orbit Observations (LEO)/Joint Polar Satellite System (JPSS) Ground Segment's Data Products and Management Services (DPMS) needs to replace the existing Arista DCS-7050TX-64-R switches which are reaching End of Service Life June 13, 2025. The LEO/JPSS program will replace the existing the Arista DCS-7050TX-64-R switches with four (4) Arista DCS-7050TX3-48C8-R switches. In addition to the procurement of the Arista switches, LEO/JPSS requires service and support for the equipment.

column5: Establish a Base + Options Contract for NOAA SATCOM Services. The NOAA Aircraft Operations Center (AOC) instruments, maintains, and operates aircraft in support of a variety of meteorological and oceanographic research projects. One of the primary requirements in a variety of missions is high reliability data and voice communications. AOC heavy aircraft (N42RF, N43RF, and N49RF) are equipped with satellite communications systems compatible with Inmarsat satellite based communications systems. Satellite communications service utilizing the Inmarsat communication satellite system are offered by a number of vendors licensed as distributors of the Inmarsat products.

column4: Maintenance of Thermo Fisher Scientific equipment
column5: Provide service and maintenance for Thermo Fisher Scientific instruments and their associated components to include uninterrupted performance within manufacturer's specifications on a scheduled and as-needed basis. The agreement guarantees the full system performance of these instruments, including third-party accessories. The Contractor shall repair/replace all parts (i.e. hardware, software, accessory components/systems) required for the operation of the systems. There are approximately 75 different instruments including mass spectrometers, detectors, autosamplers, ultra-cold freezers, pumps, etc.

column5: Lightning surge protection is required by the NWS for COOP observers whose residence or institutional facility is equipped with the Maximum Minimum Temperature System (MMTS) indoor Nimbus Display.  This protects lives and property.  The L-Com, Inc. P/N ALW-D2-05, unit arrests high voltage surges from lightning at the exterior of the building where the MMTS cable enters.  The unit provides clamping voltage down to 7.5-Volts and offers three stage protection as follows:  Stage 1, Differential Gas Discharge Tubes; Stage 2, Pair of current-limiting series resistors to 3.3 Ohms (very important); and Stage 3, Low capacitance diode array.  The part ALW-D2-05, offers two channels with paired circuits (for failover), however only one is needed for the analog signal cable that is use with the MMTS thermometer (Belden Cable P/N 9802).  See the SPEC Sheet from L-COM, attached to this Requirements Statement. The L-COM (Infinite Electronics, Irvine,

column4: Ultra-Performance Liquid Chromatography System with a Triple Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer
column5: The Contractor shall deliver an analytical instrument inclusive of one (1) Agilent model 6495D triple quadrupole mass spectrometer, and one (1) Agilent model 1290 Infinity III liquid chromatography system composed of an Agilent Infinity III High Speed Binary Pump, an Agilent 1290 Infinity III Multisampler with Multi-Wash Upgrade, and an Agilent 1290 Infinity III Multicolumn Thermostat with 6-position/14-port Quick Change Valve upgrade.  The Contractor shall deliver instrument benches for both the mass spectrometer and the chromatography system.  The Contractor shall deliver software to operate the instrumentation and perform qualitative and quantitative analyses on LC-MS/MS data and software to analyze proteomic data with spectral deconvolution capabilities.

column5: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) campuses in Boulder, Colorado and Fort Collins, Colorado consist of physical laboratories, support structures, and office buildings that have various ages of construction ranging from the mid-1900s to today. These structures are constantly being renovated or adapted for the tenants of the space depending on current experiments and these structures have known or unknown asbestos and other regulated building materials that require proper handling, surveillance and disposal prior to disturbance. NIST is responsible for providing a safe working environment for the scientists, support staff and maintenance personnel that work in these buildings and areas

column5: The Government intends to procure communications technology research services to provide scientific and technical services that consist of the following: Reduction of NIST’s 28 GHz Target Measurement to Support 3rd Generation Partnership Project’s (3GPP) JCAS Channel Model; Integration of the 3GPP JCAS Channel Models into the NIST PHY-Layer Model Software. Deliverables shall be in the form of running code for the simulation models developed, documentation for models, and tools developed, contents for publication and public dissemination, articles and papers contributed to MATLAB community. Specifically, the contactor shall be a coauthor in at least one IEEE journal article.

column5: NOAA ENPO is seeking to partner with an innovative contractor to modernize its telecommunications operating model and technical capabilities, aligning with industry standards and future-focused strategies to support NOAA’s mission. ENPO aims to enhance its current Telecommunications Expense Management System (TEMS) capabilities and improve end-to-end business process reengineering for enterprise telecommunications program management services, collectively referred to as telecommunications support services.The requirement encompasses the following key areas, though not limited to:Maintain a Future-Focused Strategy for Federal Telecommunications: Assist ENPO in developing strategies aligned with industry standards and best practices to ensure NOAA’s telecommunications capabilities stay future-ready.Telecommunications Procurement: Efficiently manage telecommunications procurement across the enterprise by leveraging the EIS contract

column5: Sentry is a person due diligence tool designed to empower any organization to promptly search for and identify connections that individuals may have with state-sponsored risk. It identifies up to 14 potential risk signals, which are verified, evidence-based high-risk relationships between individuals and state-sponsored actors, including but not limited to government ties, military ties, and funding history. Sentry can be used to learn more about individuals working within organizations of interest or to verify the affiliations of organizations’ collaborators, partners, and contractors.

column5: The semiconductor supply chain is global, specialized, and interconnected. Chipmakers do business with thousands of individual suppliers that provide the highly complex materials and tools used to produce semiconductors. To address the lack of full visibility into the semiconductors markets supply chain and R&D ecosystem gaps NIST will conduct the measurement science, or metrology, critical to the development of new materials, packaging, and production methods in chip manufacturing.¿The project requires the spectrometer upgrade to advance electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurements in complex compound semiconductors, such as chalcogenides, nitrides and oxides.Division 642, Materials Science and Engineering Division (MSED) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) is an organization whose mission includes developing techniques for structure and

column5: The Department administers policies, programs, and procedures to ensure its compliance with the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and the Privacy Act (PA), 5 U.S.C. 552 and 5 U.S.C. 552a. The Department's regulations on public records are found in 15 CFR Part 4. The FOIA generally provides that any person has the right to obtain access to federal agency records except to the extent those records are protected from disclosure by the FOIA. The PA provides individuals with a means to access government records about themselves. The right of access under the FOIA and PA is similar, and the statutes do overlap, but not entirely. The Department processes over 2000 FOIA requests per year.Department Organizational Order (10-5) prescribes the authority and functions of the Chief Financial Officer and Assistant Secretary for Administration (CFO/ASA). The CFO/ASA assigns responsibility for administering the Department’s FOIA and PA programs to

column5: This Jamf yearly license renewal. Jamf allows for CAC Card Authentication, policy management from a centralized program.   NOAA’s Global Monitoring Laboratory conducts sustained observations and research related to source and sink strengths, trends and global distributions of atmospheric constituents that are capable of forcing change in the climate of Earth through modification of the atmospheric radiative environment, those that may cause depletion of the global ozone layer, and those that affect baseline air quality.

column4: Digital Asset Management for Research and CHIPS Metrology
column5: The Open Government Data Act, Title II of the Evidence Act (P.L. 115-435), requires NIST to inventory its data and make information available to the public as machine-readable data. The White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) directs NIST to make all results of federally funded research available to the public.  Most recently the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022  (15 USC §4645) calls for the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to “carry out a microelectronics research program to enable advances and breakthroughs in measurement science, standards, material characterization, instrumentation, testing, and manufacturing capabilities that will accelerate the underlying research and development for metrology of next-generation microelectronics and ensure the competitiveness and leadership of the United States within this sector.”    This effort is a follow-on to a prior project - Digital A

column4: TAX-25-075, Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) Principal Membership
column5: On behalf of NOAA, NESDIS/ACIO-S is acquiring a Principal Membership in Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) to fulfill its mission and its functions. The NOAA National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service (NESDIS) /Assistant Chief Information Officer (ACIO) mission and function is a leadership role in the NOAA-wide development of the NOAA Integrated Earth Observation and Data Management systems architecture. Fundamental to its approach in generating guidelines for the implementation of data management capabilities is the commitment to support and leverage the efforts of organizations that are developing open standards to enableand enhance data system interoperability. The Open Geospatial Consortium, Inc. (OGC) is a nonprofit, international, voluntary consensus standards organization that was formed to coordinate the development of open standards for geospatial and location-based services. column5: The Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) Cyber Security Division (CSD) are requesting a renewal of their Red Hat software, maintenance and support. NOAA has been purchasing, maintaining, and using Red Hat software for many years. This software has been integrated into distributed systems across all NOAA offices. Therefore, NOAA requires Red Hat software maintenance (to include technical support, software updates, and software upgrades) to be purchased annually in order to meet its operational and mission requirements.

column4: MISSION CRITICAL: Emprise SAMM onboarding for NOAA Ship Oceanographer
column5: SAMM Enrolment for NOAA Ship Oceanographer. Emprise SAMM is NOAA's system of record for maintenance. As a new build, setting up NOAA Ship Oceanographer in our maintenance system of record is vital to the safe operation of the vessel. This contract modification will allow Emprise to establish Oceanographer as a new vessel in SAMM and build out the ship's technical library for maintenance actions and scheduling; this is required to be accomplished prior to making the vessel ready for operations in support of NOAA's mission as scheduled and approved by NOAA leadership.
